text: He shewed, that the advantage of an interchange of commodities between
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nations consists simply and solely in this, that it enables each to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obtain, with a given amount of labour and capital, a greater quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all commodities taken together. This it accomplishes by enabling each,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with a quantity of one commodity which has cost it so much labour and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, to purchase a quantity of another commodity which, if produced
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at home, would have required labour and capital to a greater amount.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: To render the importation of an article more advantageous than its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production, it is not necessary that the foreign country should be able
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to produce it with less labour and capital than ourselves. We may even
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have a positive advantage in its production: but, if we are so far
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: favoured by circumstances as to have a still greater positive advantage
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the production of some other article which is in demand in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and capital by employing none of it in producing the article in which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: our advantage is least, but devoting it all to the production of that in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which our advantage is greatest, and giving this to the foreign country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in exchange for the other. It is not a difference in the _absolute_ cost
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of production, which determines the interchange, but a difference in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: In order to apply this principle, with any advantage, to the solution of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the question which now occupies us, the principle itself, and the idea
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: It is well known that the quantity of any commodity which can be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disposed of, varies with the price. The higher the price, the fewer will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be the purchasers, and the smaller the quantity sold. The lower the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price, the greater will in general be the number of purchasers, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater the quantity disposed of. This is true of almost all commodities
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whatever: though of some commodities, to diminish the consumption in any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: given degree would require a much greater rise of price than of others.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Whatever be the commodity--the supply in any market being given, there
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is some price at which the whole of the supply exactly will find
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchasers, and no more. That, whatever it be, is the price at which, by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the effect of competition, the commodity will be sold. If the price be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: higher, the whole of the supply will not be disposed of, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sellers, by their competition, will bring down the price. If the price
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be lower, there will be found purchasers for a larger supply, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: competition of these purchasers will raise the price.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: exactly as she was before the trade commenced. It would be for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest, however, of Germany herself, to keep her linen a little below
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the value at which it could be produced in England, in order to keep
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: herself from being supplanted by the home producer. England, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would always benefit in some degree by the existence of the trade,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: though it might be in a very trifling one.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But in general there will not be this extreme inequality in the degree
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in which the demand in the two countries varies with variations in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price. The advantage will probably be divided equally, oftener than in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any one unequal ratio that can be named; though the division will be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much oftener, on the whole, unequal than equal.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2. We shall now examine whether the same law of interchange, which we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have shown to apply upon the supposition of barter, holds good after the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: introduction of money. Mr. Ricardo found that his more general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proposition stood this test; and as the proposition which we have just
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demonstrated is only a further developement of his principle, we shall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: probably find that it suffers a little, by a mere change in the mode
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (for it is no more) in which one commodity is exchanged against another.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We may at first make whatever supposition we will with respect to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: value of money. Let us suppose, therefore, that before the opening of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the trade, the price of cloth is the same in both countries, namely, six
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shillings per yard [2]. As 10 yards of cloth were supposed to exchange in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England for 5 yards of linen, in Germany for 20, we must suppose that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: linen is sold in England at four shillings per yard, in Germany at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: three. Cost of carriage and importer's profit are left as before, out of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consideration.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In this state of prices, cloth, it is evident, cannot yet be exported
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from England into Germany. But linen can be imported from Germany into
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England. It will be so, and, in the first instance, the linen will be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paid for in money.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The efflux of money from England, and its influx into Germany, will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: raise money prices in the latter country, and lower them in the former.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Linen will rise in Germany above three shillings per yard, and cloth
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: above six shillings. Linen in England being imported from Germany, will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (since cost of carriage is not reckoned) sink to the same price as in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that country, while cloth will fall below six shillings. As soon as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price of cloth is lower in England than in Germany, it will begin to be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exported, and the price of cloth in Germany will fall to what it is in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England. As long As the cloth exported does not suffice to pay for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: linen imported, money will continue to flow from England into Germany,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and prices generally will continue to fall in England, and rise in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany. By the fall, however, of cloth in England, cloth will fall in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany also, and the demand for it will increase. By the rise of linen
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in Germany, linen must rise in England also, and the demand for it will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminish. Although the increased exportation of cloth takes place at a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: lower price, and the diminished importation of linen at a higher, yet
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the total money value of the exportation would probably increase, that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the importation diminish. As cloth fell in price and linen rose,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there would be some particular price of both articles at-which the cloth
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exported, and the linen imported, would exactly pay for each other. At
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this point prices would remain, because money would then cease to move
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: out of England into Germany. What this point might be, would entirely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: depend upon the circumstances and inclinations of the purchasers on both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sides. If the fall of cloth did not much increase the demand for it in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany, and the rise of linen did not diminish very rapidly the demand
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for it in England, much money must pass before the equilibrium is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: restored; cloth would fall very much, and linen would rise, until
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England, perhaps, had to pay nearly as much for it as when she produced
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it for herself. But if, on the contrary, the fall of cloth caused a very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rapid increase of the demand for it in Germany, and the rise of linen in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany reduced very rapidly the demand in England from what it was
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: under the influence of the first cheapness produced by the opening of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the trade; the cloth would very soon suffice to pay for the linen,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: little money would pass between the two countries, and England would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: derive a large portion of the benefit of the trade. We have thus arrived
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at precisely the same conclusion, in supposing the employment of money,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which we found to hold under the supposition of barter.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In what shape the benefit accrues to the two nations from the trade, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: clear enough. Germany, before the commencement of the trade, paid six
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shillings per yard for broad-cloth. She now obtains it at a lower price.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, however, is not the whole of her advantage. As the money prices of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all her other commodities have risen, the money incomes of all her
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producers have increased. This is no advantage to them in buying from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: each other; because the price of what they buy has risen in the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ratio with their means of paying for it: but it is an advantage to them
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in buying any thing which has not risen; and still more, any thing which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: has fallen. They therefore benefit as consumers of cloth, not merely to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the extent to which cloth has fallen, but also to the extent to which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other prices have risen. Suppose that this is one-tenth. The same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion of their money incomes as before, will suffice to supply
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their other wants, and the remainder, being increased one-tenth in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: amount, will enable them to purchase one-tenth more cloth than before,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: even though cloth had not fallen. But it has fallen: so that they are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: doubly gainers. If they do not choose to increase their consumption of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth, this does not prevent them from being gainers. They purchase the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: same quantity with less money, and have more to expend upon their other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wants.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In England, on the contrary, general money-prices have fallen. Linen,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: however, has fallen more than the rest; having been lowered in price, by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: importation from a country where it was cheaper, whereas the others have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fallen only from the consequent efflux of money. Notwithstanding,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, the general fall of money-prices, the English producers will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be exactly as they were in all other respects, while they will gain as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchasers of linen.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The greater the efflux of money required to restore the equilibrium, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater will be the gain of Germany; both by the fall of cloth, and by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the rise of her general prices. The less the efflux of money requisite,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the greater will be the gain of England; because the price of linen will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: continue lower, and her general prices will not be reduced so much. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must not, however, be imagined that high money-prices are a good, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: low money-prices an evil, in themselves. But the higher the general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money-prices in any country, the greater will be that country's means
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of purchasing those commodities which, being imported from abroad, are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: independent of the causes which keep prices high at home.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 3. We have hitherto supposed the carriage to be performed without labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or expense. If we abandon this supposition, we must correct the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: statement of the case in a slight degree. The prices of the two articles
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will no longer, when the trade is opened, be the same in both countries,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nor will the articles exchange for one another at the same rate in both.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Ten yards of cloth will purchase in Germany a quantity of linen greater
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than in England by a per-centage equal to the entire cost of conveyance
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: both of the cloth to Germany and of the linen to England. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money-price of linen will be higher in England than in Germany, by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of carriage of the linen. The money-price of cloth will be higher
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in Germany than in England, by the cost of carriage of the cloth.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The expense of the carriage is evidently a deduction _pro tanto_ from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the saving of labour produced by the establishment of the trade. The two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: countries together, therefore, have their gains by the trade diminished,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by the amount of the cost of carriage of both commodities. But here the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: question arises, which of the two countries bears this deduction, or in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: what proportion it is divided between them.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: At the first inspection it would appear that each country bears its own
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of carriage, that is, that each country pays the carriage of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodity which it imports. Upon this supposition, each country would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gain whatever share of the joint saving of labour would otherwise fall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to its lot, _minus_ the cost of bringing from the other country the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodity which it imports. This solution is rendered plausible by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: circumstance just now mentioned, that the price of the commodity will be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: higher in the country which imports it, than in the country which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exports it, by the amount of the cost of carriage. If linen is sold in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England at a higher price than in Germany, by a per-centage equal to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of carriage of the linen, it appears obvious that England pays for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the carriage of the linen, and Germany, by parity of reason, for that of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the cloth.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But if we apply to these questions the principles already explained, we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shall see that this is not by any means a universal law: the fact may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: correspond with it, or it may not.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: For suppose that the prices have adjusted themselves, no matter how, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the imports and exports balance one another, each commodity, of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: course, being dearer by the cost of carriage, in the country which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imports than in that which exports it: and suppose now that the cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carriage, both of the one and of the other, were suddenly and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: miraculously annihilated, and that the commodities could pass from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country to country without expense. If each country bore its own cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carriage before, each country will save its own cost of carriage now.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Cloth, in Germany, will in that case fall exactly to what it is in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England; linen in England, to what it is in Germany.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now this fall of price, supposing it to happen, will probably affect the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand on both sides; and it will either affect it alike in both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: countries, or it will affect it unequally. It will affect it alike, if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the fall of price does not affect the demand at all, or if it affects it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equally in both countries. If either of these results should take place,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the cloth and the linen would continue to balance each other as before:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no money would pass from one country to the other; prices in both would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: continue at the point to which they had fallen, and each country would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exactly save the cost of carriage on the commodity which it imports from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the other.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But the result might be, that the fall of price might not have an effect
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exactly equal, on the demand in the two countries. Suppose, for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instance, that the fall of cloth in Germany owing to the saving of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of carriage, did not increase the demand for cloth in Germany; but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the fall of linen in England from a like cause, did increase the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand for linen in England. The linen imported would be more than could
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be paid for by the cloth exported: the difference must be paid in money:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the change in the distribution of the precious metals between the two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: countries would lower the price of cloth in England, (and consequently
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in Germany), while it would raise the price of linen in Germany, (and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequently in England). Germany, therefore, by the annihilation of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of carriage, would save in price more than the cost of carriage of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the cloth; England would save less in price than the cost of carriage of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the linen. But if by the miraculous annihilation of cost of carriage,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England would not _save_ the whole of the carriage of her imports, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: follows that England did not previously _pay_ the whole of that cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carriage.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Thus, the division of the cost of trade, and the division of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage of trade, are governed by precisely the same principles; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the only general proposition which can be affirmed respecting the cost
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is, that it is _pro tanto_ a deduction from the advantage. It cannot
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: even be maintained that the cost is shared in the same proportion as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage is; because the increase of the demand for a commodity as its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price falls, is not governed by any fixed law. Suppose, for instance,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the advantage happened to be divided equally: this must be because
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the greater cheapness arising from the establishment of the trade,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: either did not affect the demand at all, or affected it in an equal
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion on both sides. Now, because such is the effect of the degree
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of increased cheapness resulting from importation burthened with cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carriage, it would not follow that the still greater degree of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cheapness, produced by the additional saving of the cost of carriage
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: itself, would also affect the demand of both countries in precisely an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equal degree. But we cannot be said to bear an expense, which, if saved,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be saved to somebody else, and not to us. Two countries may have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equal shares of the clear benefit of the trade, while, if the cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carriage were saved, they would divide that saving unequally. If so,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they divide the gross gain in one unequal ratio, the cost in another
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unequal ratio, though their shares of the cost being deducted from their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shares of the gain leave equal remainders.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 4. The question naturally suggests itself, whether any country, by its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own legislative policy, can engross to itself a larger share of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: benefits of foreign commerce, than would fall to it in the natural or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: spontaneous course of trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The answer is, it can. By taxing exports, for instance, we may, under
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: certain circumstances, produce a division of the advantage of the trade
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more favourable to ourselves. In some cases, we may draw into our
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: coffers, at the expense of foreigners, not only the whole tax, but more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than the tax: in other cases, we should gain exactly the tax,--in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: others, less than the tax. In this last case, a part of the tax is borne
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by ourselves: possibly the whole, possibly even, as we shall show, more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than the whole.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Suppose that England taxes her export of cloth: the tax not being
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: supposed high enough to induce Germany to produce cloth for herself. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price at which cloth can be sold in Germany is augmented by the tax.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This will probably diminish the quantity consumed. It may diminish it so
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much, that even at the increased price, there will not be required so
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: great a money value as before. It may diminish it in such a ratio, that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the money value of the quantity consumed will be exactly the same as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: before. Or it may not diminish it at all, or so little, that, in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequence of the higher price, a greater money value will be purchased
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than before. In this last case, England will gain, at the expense of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany, not only the whole amount of the duty, but more. For the money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: value of her exports to Germany being increased, while her imports
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remain the same, money will flow into England from Germany. The price of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth will rise in England, and consequently in Germany; but the price
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of linen will fall in Germany, and consequently in England, We shall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: export less cloth, and import more linen, till the equilibrium is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: restored. It thus appears, what is at first sight somewhat remarkable,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that, by taxing her exports, England would, under some conceivable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: circumstances, not only gain from her foreign customers the whole amount
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the tax, but would also get her imports cheaper. She would get them
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cheaper in two ways,--for she would obtain them for less money, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would have more money to purchase them with. Germany, on the other hand,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would suffer doubly: she would have to pay for her cloth a price
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increased not only by the duty, but by the influx of money into England,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: while the same change in the distribution of the circulating medium
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would leave her less money to purchase it with.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, however, is only one of three possible cases. If, after the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imposition of the duty, Germany requires so diminished a quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth, that its total money value is exactly the same as before, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: balance of trade will be undisturbed; England will gain the duty,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany will lose it, and nothing more. If, again, the imposition of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: duty occasions such a falling off in the demand, that Germany requires a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: less pecuniary value than before, our exports will no longer pay for our
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imports, money must pass from England into Germany, and Germany's share
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the advantage of the trade will be increased. By the change in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distribution of money, cloth will fall in England; and therefore it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will, of course, fall in Germany. Thus Germany will not pay the whole of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the tax. From the same cause, linen will rise in Germany, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequently in England. When this alteration of prices has so adjusted
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the demand, that the cloth and the linen again pay for one another, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: result is, that Germany has paid only a part of the tax, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remainder of what has been received into our treasury has come
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indirectly out of the pockets of our own consumers of linen, who pay a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: higher price for that imported commodity, in consequence of the tax on
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: our exports, which at the same time they, in consequence of the efflux
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of money and consequent fall of prices, have smaller money incomes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wherewith to pay for the linen at that advanced price.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is not an impossible supposition that, by taxing our exports, we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: might not only gain nothing from the foreigner, the tax being paid out
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of our own pockets, but might even compel our own people to pay a second
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tax to the foreigner. Suppose, as before, that the demand of Germany for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth falls off so much on the imposition of the duty, that she requires
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a smaller money value than before, but that the case is so different
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with linen in England, that when the price rises the demand either does
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not fall off at all, or so little that the money value required is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater than before. The first effect of laying on the duty is, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: before, that the cloth exported will no longer pay for the linen
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imported. Money will, therefore, flow out of England into Germany. One
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: effect is to raise the price of linen in Germany, and, consequently, in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England. But this, by the supposition, instead of stopping the efflux of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money, only makes it greater, because the higher the price, the greater
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the money value of the linen consumed. The balance, therefore, can only
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be restored by the other effect, which is going on at the same time,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: namely, the fall of cloth in the English, and, consequently, in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: German market. Even when cloth has fallen so low that its price with the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: duty is only equal to what its price without the duty was at first, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is not a necessary consequence that the fall will stop; for the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: amount of exportation as before will not now suffice to pay the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increased money value of the imports; and although the German consumers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have now not only cloth at the old price, but likewise increased money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: incomes, it is not certain that they will be inclined to employ the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increase of their incomes in increasing their purchases of cloth. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price of cloth, therefore, must perhaps fall, to restore the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equilibrium, more than the whole amount of the duty; Germany may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enabled to import cloth at a lower price when it is taxed, than when it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: was untaxed: and this gain she will acquire at the expense of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: English consumers of linen, who, in addition, will be the real payers of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the whole of what is received at their own custom-house under the name
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of duties on the export of cloth.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Such are the extremely various effects which may result to ourselves,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and to our customers, from the imposition of taxes on our exports [3]:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and the determining circumstances are of a nature so imperfectly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ascertainable, that it must be almost impossible to decide with any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: certainty, even after the tax has been imposed, whether we have been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gainers by it or losers. It is certain, however, that whatever we gain,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is lost by somebody else, and there is the expense of the collection
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: besides: if international morality, therefore, were rightly understood
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and acted upon, such taxes, as being contrary to the universal weal,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would not exist. Moreover, the imposition of such a tax frequently will,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and always may, expose a country to lose this branch of its trade
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: altogether, or to carry it on with diminished advantage, in consequence
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the competition of untaxed exporters from other countries, or of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: domestic producers in the country to which it exports. Even on the most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: selfish principles, therefore, the benefit of such a tax is always
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: extremely precarious.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 5. We have had an example of a tax on exports, that is, on foreigners,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: falling in part on ourselves. We shall, therefore, not be surprised if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: we find a tax on imports, that is, on ourselves, partly falling upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: foreigners.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Instead of taxing the cloth which we export, suppose that we tax the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: linen which we import. The duty which we are now supposing must not be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: what is termed a protecting duty, that is, a duty sufficiently high to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: induce us to produce the article at home. If it had this effect, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would destroy entirely the trade both in cloth and in linen, and both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: countries would lose the whole of the advantage which they previously
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gained by exchanging those commodities with one another. We suppose a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: duty which might diminish the consumption of the article, but which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would not prevent us from continuing to import, as before, whatever
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: linen we did consume.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The equilibrium of trade would be disturbed if the imposition of the tax
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminished in the slightest degree the quantity of linen consumed. For,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as the tax is levied at our own custom-house, the German exporter only
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receives the same price as formerly, though the English consumer pays a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: higher one. If, therefore, there be any diminution of the quantity
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: bought, although a larger sum of money may be actually laid out in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: article, a smaller one will be due from England to Germany: this sum
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will no longer be an equivalent for the sum due from Germany to England
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for cloth, the balance therefore must be paid in money. Prices will fall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in Germany, and rise in England; linen will fall in the German market;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth will rise in the English. The Germans will pay higher price for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth, and will have smaller money incomes to buy it with; while the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: English will obtain linen cheaper, that is, its price will exceed what
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it previously was by less than the amount of the duty, while their means
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of purchasing it will be increased by the increase of their money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: incomes.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the imposition of the tax does not diminish the demand, it will leave
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the trade exactly as it was before. We shall import as much, and export
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as much; the whole of the tax will be paid out of our own pockets.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But the imposition of a tax on a commodity, almost always diminishes the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand more or less; and it can never, or scarcely ever increase the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand. It may, therefore, be laid down as a principle, that a tax on
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imported commodities, when it really operates as a tax, and not as a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: prohibition, either total or partial, almost always falls in part upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the foreigners who consume our goods: and that this is a mode in which a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nation may be almost sure of appropriating to itself, at the expense of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: foreigners, a larger share than would otherwise belong to it of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increase in the general productiveness of the labour and capital of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: world, which results from the interchange of commodities among nations.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is scarcely necessary to observe, that no such advantage can result
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from the duty, if it operate as a protecting duty; if it induce the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country which imposes it, to produce for herself that which she would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: otherwise have imported. The saving of labour--the increase in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general productiveness of the capital of the world--which is the effect
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of commerce, and which a non-protecting duty would enable the country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imposing it to engross, could not be engrossed by a protecting duty,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because such a duty prevents any such increased production from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: existing.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: With a view to practical legislation, therefore, duties on importation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: may be divided into two classes: those which have the effect of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: encouraging some particular branch of domestic industry, and those which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have not.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The former are purely mischievous, both to the country imposing them,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and to those with whom it trades. They prevent a saving of labour and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, which, if permitted to be made, would be divided in some
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion or other between the importing country and the countries
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which buy what that country does or might export.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The other class of duties are those which do not encourage one mode of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: procuring an article at the expense of another, but allow interchange to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: take place just as if the duty did not exist--and to produce the saving
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of labour which constitutes the motive to international as to all other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commerce. Of this kind, are duties on the importation of any commodity
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which could not by any possibility be produced at home; and duties not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficiently high to counterbalance the difference of expense between
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the production of the article at home, and its importation. Of the money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which is brought into the treasury of any country by taxes of this last
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: description, a part only is paid by the people of that country; the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remainder by the foreign consumers of their goods.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Nevertheless, this latter kind of taxes are in principle as ineligible
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as the former, although not precisely on the same ground. A protecting
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: duty can never be a cause of gain, but always and necessarily of loss,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the country imposing it, just so far as it is efficacious to its end.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: A non-protecting duty on the contrary would, in most cases, be a source
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of gain to the country imposing it, in so far as throwing part of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: weight of its taxes upon other people is a gain; but it would be a means
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of gain which it could seldom be advisable to adopt, being so easily
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: counteracted by a precisely similar proceeding on the other side.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If England, in the case already supposed, sought to obtain for herself
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more than her natural share of the advantage of the trade with Germany,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by imposing a duty upon cloth, Germany would only have to impose a duty
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon linen, sufficient to diminish the demand for that article about as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much as the demand for cloth had been diminished in England by the tax.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Things would then be as before, and each country would pay its own tax.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Unless, indeed, the sum of the two duties exceeded the entire advantage
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the trade; for in that case the trade, and its advantage, would cease
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: entirely.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There would be no advantage, therefore, in imposing duties of this kind,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with a view to gain by them, in the manner which has been pointed out.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But so long as any other kind of taxes on commodities are retained, as a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: source of revenue, these may often be as unobjectionable as the rest. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is evident, moreover, that considerations of reciprocity, which are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quite unessential when the matter in debate is a protecting duty, are of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: material importance when the repeal of duties of this other description
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is discussed. A country cannot be expected to renounce the power of

text: 6. Any cause which alters the exports or imports from one country into
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: another, alters the division of the advantage of interchange between
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those two countries. Suppose the discovery of a new process, by which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: countries, and lowers the prices of all articles imported from them,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: discovery.

text: would have fallen to if trade had been left free.
