text: By another obvious application of the same reasoning, it will be seen,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that there is a real foundation for the notion, that a country may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: benefited by receiving from another country the concession of what used
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to be termed commercial advantages, or by restraining its colonies from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchasing goods of any country except itself. In the figured
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: illustration last used (p. 34) [not available, M.D.], it is evident,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that if England had been bound by a treaty with Germany to buy linen
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exclusively from her, Germany would have retained the trade which we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: supposed her to lose, and would have continued to purchase cloth at a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comparatively cheap rate from England, instead of producing it by a more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: costly process at home. Suppose that England had been a colony of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany, and we see that by compelling colonies to deal at her shop, she
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: may obtain a real advantage, though of a nature which we may hazard the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: assertion that the founders of our colonial policy little dreamt of.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Such an advantage, however, being gained at the expense of another
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country, is, at the least, simply equivalent to a tax, or tribute. Now,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: if a country has just grounds, or deems superiority of power a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient ground, for exacting a tribute from another country, the most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: direct mode is the best. First, because it is the most intelligible, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: has least of trick or disguise. Secondly, because it allows the people
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the country paying the tribute, to raise the money in whatever way
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they consider least oppressive to themselves. Thirdly, because the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indirect mode of taxing a country, by restrictions on its commerce,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disturbs the distribution of industry most advantageous to the world at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: large, and occasions a greater loss to the restricted country, and to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the other countries with which that country would have traded, than gain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the country in whose favour the restrictions are imposed. And lastly,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because a country never could obtain such privileges from an independent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nation, and has seldom been so undisguised an oppressor as to demand
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them even from its colonies, without subjecting itself to restrictions
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in some degree equivalent, for the benefit of those whom it has thus
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: taxed. Each country, therefore, usually pays tribute to the other; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to produce this fruitless reciprocity of exaction, the industry and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: trade of both countries are diverted from the most advantageous
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: channels, and the return to the labour and capital of both is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminished, in pure loss.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 9. The same principles which have led to the above conclusions, also
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: suggest a remark of some importance with respect to the probable effect
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a change from a restricted to a comparatively free trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There is no doubt that our prohibiting the importation of a particular
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: article, which, but for the prohibition, would have been imported,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enables us to obtain our other imports at smaller cost. The article for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which we have the greatest demand, and for which our demand is most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increased by cheapness, is that which we should naturally import
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: preferably to any other; now of this article we should import the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quantity necessary to pay for our exports, on terms of interchange less
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantageous to us than in the case of any other commodity. If our
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: legislature prohibits this commodity, the other country will be obliged
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to offer any other article on easier terms, in order to force a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient demand for it to be an equivalent to what she purchases from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: us.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The steps of the process, money being used, would be these:--We prohibit
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the importation of linen. The exportation of cloth continues, but is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paid for in money. Our prices rise, those in Germany fall, until silk,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or some other article, can be imported from Germany cheaper than it can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be produced at home, and in sufficient abundance to balance the export
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of cloth. Thus by sacrificing the cheapness of one commodity, we gain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the cheapness of another: but we sacrifice a greater cheapness to gain a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: less, and we sacrifice cheapness in the article which we most want, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would import by preference, while our compensation is cheapness in an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: article which we either could produce more advantageously at home, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which we have so little desire for, that it requires a species of bounty
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: on the article to create a demand.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Restrictions on importation do, however, tend to keep down the value and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price of our remaining imports, and to keep up the nominal or money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: prices of all our other commodities, by retaining a greater quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money in the country than would otherwise be there. From this it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obviously follows, that if the restrictions were removed, we should have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to pay rather more for some of the articles which we now import, while
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those which we are now prevented from importing would cost us more than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: might be inferred from their _present_ price in the foreign market. And
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general prices would fall; to the benefit of those who have fixed sums
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to receive; to the disadvantage of those who have fixed sums to pay; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: giving rise, as a general fall of prices always does, to an appearance,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: though a temporary and fallacious one, of general distress. [5]
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is right to observe that the measures of the British Legislature
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which have been falsely characterised as measures of free trade, must,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from their extremely insignificant extent, have produced far too little
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: effect in increasing our importation, to have actually led, in any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: degree worth mentioning, to the results specified above.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is of greater importance to take notice, that these effects may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: entirely obviated, if foreign countries can be prevailed upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: simultaneously to relax their restrictive systems, so as to create an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: immediate increase of demand for our exports at the present prices. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is true that exports and imports must, in the end, balance one another,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and if we increase our imports, our exports will of necessity increase
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: too. But it is a forced increase, produced by an efflux of money and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fall of prices; and this fall of prices being permanent, although it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be no evil at all in a country where credit is unknown, it may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a very serious one where large classes of persons, and the nation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: itself, are under engagements to pay fixed sums of money of large
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: amount.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 10. The only remaining application of the principle set forth in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: essay, which we think it of importance to notice specially, is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: effect produced upon a country by the annual payment of a tribute or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subsidy to a foreign power, or by the annual remittance of rents to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: absentee landlords, or of any other kind of income to its absent owners.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Remittances to absentees are often very incorrectly likened in their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general character to the payment of a tribute; from which they differ in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this very material circumstance, that tribute, if not paid to a foreign
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country, is not paid at all, whereas rents are paid to the landlord, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumed by him, even if he resides at home. The two kinds of payment,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: however, have a perfect resemblance to each other in such parts of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: effects as we are about to point out.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The tribute, subsidy, or remittance, is always in goods; for, unless the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country possesses mines of the precious metals, and numbers those metals
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: among its regular articles of export, it cannot go on, year after year,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: parting with them, and never receiving them back. When a nation has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: regular payments to make in a foreign country, for which it is not to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receive any return, its exports must annually exceed its imports by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: amount of the payments which it is bound so to make. In order to force a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand for its exports greater than its imports will suffice to pay for,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it must offer them at a rate of interchange more favourable to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: foreign country, and less so to itself, than if it had no payments to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: make beyond the value of its imports. It therefore carries on the trade
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with less advantage, in consequence of the obligations to which it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subject towards persons resident in foreign countries.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The steps of the process are these. The exports and imports being in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equilibrium, suppose a treaty to be concluded, by which the country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: binds itself to pay in tribute to another country, a certain sum
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: annually. It makes, perhaps, the first payment by a remittance of money.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This lowers prices in the paying country, and raises them in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receiving one: the exports of the tributary country increase, its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: imports diminish. When the efflux of money has altered prices in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: requisite degree, the exports exceed the imports annually, by the amount
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the tribute; and the latter, being added to the sum of the payments
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: due, restores the balance of payments between the two countries. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: result to the tributary country is a diminution of her share in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage of foreign trade. She pays dearer for her imports, in two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ways, because she pays more money, and because that money is of higher
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: value, the money incomes of her inhabitants being of smaller amount.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Thus the imposition of a tribute is a double burthen to the country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paying it, and a double gain to that which receives it. The tributary
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country pays to the other, first, the tax, whatever be its amount, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: next, something more, which the one country loses in the increased cost
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of its imports, the other gains in the diminished cost of its own.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Absenteeism, moreover, though not burthensome in the former of these
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ways, since the money is paid whether the receiver be an absentee or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not, is yet disadvantageous in the second of the two modes which have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been mentioned. Ireland pays dearer for her imports in consequence of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: her absentees; a circumstance which the assailants of Mr. M'Culloch,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whether political economists or not, have not, we believe, hitherto
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thought of producing against him.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 11. If the question be now asked, which of the countries of the world
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gains most by foreign commerce, the following will be the answer.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If by gain be meant advantage, in the most enlarged sense, that country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will generally gain the most, which stands most in need of foreign
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But if by gain be meant saving of labour and capital in obtaining the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities which the country desires to have, whatever they may be; the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country will gain, not in proportion to its own need of foreign
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: articles, but to the need which foreigners have of the articles which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: itself produces.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us take, as an illustration of our meaning, the case of France and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England. Those two nations, in consequence of the restrictions with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which they have loaded their commercial intercourse, carry on so little
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: trade with each other, as may almost, regard being had to the wealth and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: population of the two countries, be called none at all. If these fetters
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: were at once taken off, which of the two countries would be the greatest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gainer? England without doubt. There would instantly arise in France an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: immense demand for the cottons, woollens, and iron of England; while
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wines, brandies, and silks, the staple articles of France, are less
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: likely to come into general demand here, nor would the consumption of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: such productions, it is probable, be so rapidly increased by the fall of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price. The fall would probably be very great before France could obtain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a vent in England for so much of her exports as would suffice to pay for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the probable amount of her imports. There would be a considerable flow
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the precious metals out of France into England. The English consumer
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of French wine would not merely save the amount of the duty which that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wine now pays, but would find the wine itself falling-in prime cost,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: while his means of purchasing it would be increased by the augmentation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of his own money income. The French consumer of English cottons, on the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: contrary, would not long continue to be able to purchase them at the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price they now sell for in England. He would gain less, as the English
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would gain more, than might appear from a mere comparison between the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: present prices of commodities in the two countries.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Various consequences would flow from opening the trade between France
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and England, which are not expected, either by the friends or by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: opponents of the present restrictive system. The wine-growers of France,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who imagine that free trade would relieve their distress by raising the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price of their wine, might not improbably find that price actually
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: lowered. On the other hand, our silk manufacturers would be surprised if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they were told that the free admission of our cottons and hardware into
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the French market, would endanger _their_ branch of manufacture: yet
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: such might very possibly be the effect. France, it is likely, could most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantageously pay us in silks for a portion of the large amount of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cottons and hardware which we should sell to her; and though our silk
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: manufacturers may now be able to compete advantageously, in some
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: branches of the manufacture, with their French rivals, it by no means
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: follows that they could do so when the efflux of money from France, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its influx into England, had lowered the price of silk goods in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: French market, and increased all the expenses of production here.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: On the whole, England probably, of all the countries of Europe, draws to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: herself the largest share of the gains of international commerce:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because her exportable articles are in universal demand, and are of such
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a kind that the demand increases rapidly as the price falls. Countries
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which export food, have the former advantage, but not the latter. But
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: our own colonies, and the countries which supply us with the materials
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of our manufactures, maintain a hard struggle with us for an equal share

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: [4] The world at large, sellers and buyers taken together, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: always a gainer by underselling. If, in the case supposed, England were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: compelled by a commercial treaty to exclude the linen of Flanders from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: her market, the total wealth of the world, if affected at all, would be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminished.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: For, what is the cause which enables Flanders to undersell Germany? That
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Flanders, if she had the trade, would exchange linen for cloth at a rate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of interchange more advantageous to England. And why can Flanders do so?
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It must be either because Flanders can produce the article with a less
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comparative quantity of labour than Germany, and therefore the total
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage to be divided between the two countries is greater in the case
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of Flanders than of Germany; or else because, though the total advantage
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is not greater, Flanders obtains a less share of it, her demand for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cloth being greater, at the same rate of interchange, than that of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Germany. In the former case, to exclude Flemish linen from England would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be to prevent the world at large from making a greater saving of labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instead of a less. In the latter, the exclusion would be inefficacious
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for the only end it could be intended for, viz., the benefit of Germany,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unless Flemish money were excluded from England as well as Flemish
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: linen. For Flanders would buy English cloth, paying for it in money,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: until the fall of her prices enabled her to pay for it with something
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: else: and the ultimate result would be that, by the rise of prices in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England, Germany must pay a higher price for her cloth, and so lose a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: part of the advantage in spite of the treaty; while England would pay
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for German linen the same price indeed, but as the money incomes of her
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own people would be increased, the same money price would imply a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: smaller sacrifice.

text: Before the appearance of those great writers whose discoveries have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: given to political economy its present comparatively scientific
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: character, the ideas universally entertained both by theorists and by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: practical men, on the causes of national wealth, were grounded upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: certain general views, which almost all who have given any considerable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: attention to the subject now justly hold to be completely erroneous.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Among the mistakes which were most pernicious in their direct
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequences, and tended in the greatest degree to prevent a just
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conception of the objects of the science, or of the test to be applied
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the solution of the questions which it presents, was the immense
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: importance attached to consumption. The great end of legislation in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matters of national wealth, according to the prevalent opinion, was to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: create consumers. A great and rapid consumption was what the producers,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of all classes and denominations, wanted, to enrich themselves and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country. This object, under the varying names of an extensive demand, a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: brisk circulation, a great expenditure of money, and sometimes _totidem
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: verbis_ a large consumption, was conceived to be the great condition of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: prosperity.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is not necessary, in the present state of the science, to contest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this doctrine in the most flagrantly absurd of its forms or of its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: applications. The utility of a large government expenditure, for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purpose of encouraging industry, is no longer maintained. Taxes are not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: now esteemed to be "like the dews of heaven, which return again in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: prolific showers." It is no longer supposed that you benefit the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producer by taking his money, provided you give it to him again in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exchange for his goods. There is nothing which impresses a person of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reflection with a stronger sense of the shallowness of the political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reasonings of the last two centuries, than the general reception so long
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: given to a doctrine which, if it proves anything, proves that the more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: you take from the pockets of the people to spend on your own pleasures,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the richer they grow; that the man who steals money out of a shop,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: provided he expends it all again at the same shop, is a benefactor to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the tradesman whom he robs, and that the same operation, repeated
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficiently often, would make the tradesman's fortune.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In opposition to these palpable absurdities, it was triumphantly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: established by political economists, that consumption never needs
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: encouragement. All which is produced is already consumed, either for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purpose of reproduction or of enjoyment. The person who saves his income
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is no less a consumer than he who spends it: he consumes it in a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: different way; it supplies food and clothing to be consumed, tools and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: materials to be used, by productive labourers. Consumption, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: already takes place to the greatest extent which the amount of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production admits of; but, of the two kinds of consumption, reproductive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and unproductive, the former alone adds to the national wealth, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: latter impairs it. What is consumed for mere enjoyment, is gone; what is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumed for reproduction, leaves commodities of equal value, commonly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with the addition of a profit. The usual effect of the attempts of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: government to encourage consumption, is merely to prevent saving; that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is, to promote unproductive consumption at the expense of reproductive,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and diminish the national wealth by the very means which were intended
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to increase it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: What a country wants to make it richer, is never consumption, but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production. Where there is the latter, we may be sure that there is no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: want of the former. To produce, implies that the producer desires to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consume; why else should he give himself useless labour? He may not wish
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to consume what he himself produces, but his motive for producing and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: selling is the desire to buy. Therefore, if the producers generally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce and sell more and more, they certainly also buy more and more.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Each may not want more of what he himself produces, but each wants more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of what some other produces; and, by producing what the other wants,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hopes to obtain what the other produces. There will never, therefore, be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a greater quantity produced, of commodities in general, than there are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumers for. But there may be, and always are, abundance of persons
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who have the inclination to become consumers of some commodity, but are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unable to satisfy their wish, because they have not the means of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producing either that, or anything to give in exchange for it. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: legislator, therefore, needs not give himself any concern about
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumption. There will always be consumption for everything which can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be produced, until the wants of all who possess the means of producing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are completely satisfied, and then production will not increase any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: farther. The legislator has to look solely to two points: that no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obstacle shall exist to prevent those who have the means of producing,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from employing those means as they find most for their interest; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that those who have not at present the means of producing, to the extent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of their desire to consume, shall have every facility afforded to their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: acquiring the means, that, becoming producers, they may be enabled to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consume.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: profess to have studied the subject, and are disputed by few except
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: truths clearer than they already are, but to perform a task, so useful

text: and needful, that it is to be wished it were oftener deemed part of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: business of those who direct their assaults against ancient prejudices,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: --that of seeing that no scattered particles of important truth are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: buried and lost in the ruins of exploded error. Every prejudice, which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: has long and extensively prevailed among the educated and intelligent,

text: must certainly be borne out by some strong appearance of evidence; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: when it is found that the evidence does not prove the received
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conclusion, it is of the highest importance to see what it does prove.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: appearances is often merely exchanged for an error contrary to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: truth, and will have difficulty in obtaining credence while the false

text: to produce, everything which he required, customers and their wants

text: We shall propose for examination a very simple case, but the explanation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of which will suffice to clear up all other cases which fall within the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: same principle. Suppose that a number of foreigners with large incomes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: arrive in a country, and there expend those incomes: will this operation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be beneficial, as respects the national wealth, to the country which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receives these immigrants? Yes, say many political economists, if they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: save any part of their incomes, and employ them reproductively; because
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: then an addition is made to the national capital, and the produce is a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: clear increase of the national wealth. But if the foreigner expends all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his income unproductively, it is no benefit to the country, say they,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and for the following reason.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the foreigner had his income remitted to him in bread and beef, coats
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and shoes, and all the other articles which he was desirous to consume,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it would not be pretended that his eating, drinking, and wearing them,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: on our shores rather than on his own, could be of any advantage to us in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: point of wealth. Now, the case is not different if his income is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remitted to him in some one commodity, as, for instance, in money. For
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whatever takes place afterwards, with a view to the supply of his wants,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is a mere exchange of equivalents; and it is impossible that a person
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: should ever be enriched by merely receiving an equal value in exchange
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for an equal value.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When it is said that the purchases of the foreign consumer give
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employment to capital which would otherwise yield no profit to its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: owner, the same political economists reject this proposition as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: involving the fallacy of what has been called a "general glut." They
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: say, that the capital, which any person has chosen to produce and to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulate, can always find employment, since the fact that he has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulated it proves that he had an unsatisfied desire; and if he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cannot find anything to produce for the wants of other consumers, he can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for his own.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is impossible to contest these propositions as thus stated. But there
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is one consideration which clearly shews, that there is something more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the matter than is here taken into the account; and this is, that the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: above reasoning tends distinctly to prove, that it does a tradesman no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: good to go into his shop and buy his goods. How can he be enriched? it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: might be asked. He merely receives a certain value in money, for an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equivalent value in goods. Neither does this give employment to his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital; for there never exists more capital than can find employment,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and if one person does not buy his goods another will; or if nobody
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: does, there is over-production in that business, he can remove his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, and find employment for it in another trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Every one sees the fallacy of this reasoning as applied to individual
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producers. Every one knows that as applied to them it has not even the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: semblance of plausibility; that the wealth of a producer does in a great
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: measure depend upon the number of his customers, and that in general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: every additional purchaser does really add to his profits. If the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reasoning, which would be so absurd if applied to individuals, be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: applicable to nations, the principle on which it rests must require much
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: explanation and elucidation.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us endeavour to analyse with precision the real nature of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage which a producer derives from an addition to the number of his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: customers.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: For this purpose, it is necessary that we should premise a single
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: observation on the meaning of the word capital. It is usually defined,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the food, clothing, and other articles set aside for the consumption of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the labourer, together with the materials and instruments of production.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This definition appears to us peculiarly liable to misapprehension; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much vagueness and some narrow views have, we conceive, occasionally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: resulted from its being interpreted with too mechanical an adherence to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the literal meaning of the words.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The capital, whether of an individual or of a nation, consists, we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: apprehend, of all matters possessing exchangeable value, which the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: individual or the nation has in his or in its possession for the purpose
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of reproduction, and not for the purpose of the owner's unproductive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment. All unsold goods, therefore, constitute a part of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: national capital, and of the capital of the producer or dealer to whom
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they belong. It is true that tools, materials, and the articles on which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the labourer is supported, are the only articles which are directly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subservient to production: and if I have a capital consisting of money,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or of goods in a warehouse, I can only employ them as means of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production in so far as they are capable of being exchanged for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: articles which conduce directly to that end. But the food, machinery,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: &c, which will ultimately be purchased with the goods in my warehouse,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: may at this moment not be in the country, may not be even in existence.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If, after having sold the goods, I hire labourers with the money, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: set them to work, I am surely employing capital, though the corn, which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the form of bread those labourers may buy with the money, may be now
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in warehouse at Dantzic, or perhaps not yet above ground.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Whatever, therefore, is destined to be employed reproductively, either
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in its existing shape, or indirectly by a previous (or even subsequent)
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exchange, is capital. Suppose that I have laid out all the money I
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possess in wages and tools, and that the article I produce is just
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: completed: in the interval which elapses before I can sell the article,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: realize the proceeds, and lay them out again in wages and tools, will it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be said that I have no capital? Certainly not: I have the same capital
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as before, perhaps a greater, but it is locked up, as the expression is,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and not disposable.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When we have thus seen accurately what really constitutes capital, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: becomes obvious, that of the capital of a country, there is at all times
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a very large proportion lying idle. The annual produce of a country is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: never any thing approaching in magnitude to what it might be if all the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: resources devoted to reproduction, if all the capital, in short, of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country, were in full employment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If every commodity on an average remained unsold for a length of time
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equal to that required for its production, it is obvious that, at any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one time, no more than half the productive capital of the country would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be really performing the functions of capital. The two halves would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: relieve one another, like the semichori in a Greek tragedy; or rather
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the half which was in employment would be a fluctuating portion,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: composed of varying parts; but the result would be, that each producer
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be able to produce every year only half as large a supply of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities, as he could produce if he were sure of selling them the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: moment the production was completed.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, or something like it, is however the habitual state, at every
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instant, of a very large proportion of all the capitalists in the world.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The number of producers, or dealers, who turn over their capital, as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expression is, in the shortest possible time, is very small. There are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: few who have so rapid a sale for their wares, that all the goods which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their own capital, or the capital which they can borrow, enables them to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: supply, are carried off as fast as they can be supplied. The majority
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have not an _extent of business_, at all adequate to the amount of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital they dispose of. It is true that, in the communities in which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: industry and commerce are practised with greatest success, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: contrivances of banking enable the possessor of a larger capital than he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: can employ in his own business, to employ it productively and derive a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: revenue from it notwithstanding. Yet even then, there is, of necessity,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a great quantity of capital which remains fixed in the shape of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: implements, machinery, buildings, &c, whether it is only half employed,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or in complete employment: and every dealer keeps a stock in trade, to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be ready for a possible sudden demand, though he probably may not be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: able to dispose of it for an indefinite period.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This perpetual non-employment of a large proportion of capital, is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price we pay for the division of labour. The purchase is worth what it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: costs; but the price is considerable.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Of the importance of the fact which has just been noticed there are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: three signal proofs. One is, the large sum often given for the goodwill
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a particular business. Another is, the large rent which is paid for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shops in certain situations, near a great thoroughfare for example,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which have no advantage except that the occupier may expect a larger
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: body of customers, and be enabled to turn over his capital more quickly.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Another is, that in many trades, there are some dealers who sell
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: articles of an equal quality at a lower price than other dealers. Of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: course, this is not a voluntary sacrifice of profits: they expect by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequent overflow of customers to turn over their capital more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quickly, and to be gainers by keeping the whole of their capital in more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: constant employment, though on any given operation their gains are less.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The reasoning cited in the earlier part of this paper, to show the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: uselessness of a mere purchaser or customer, for enriching a nation or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: an individual, applies only to the case of dealers who have already as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much business as their capital admits of, and as rapid a sale for their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities as is possible. To such dealers an additional purchaser is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: really of no use; for, if they are sure of selling all their commodities
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the moment those commodities are on sale, it is of no consequence whether
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they sell them to one person or to another. But it is questionable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whether there be any dealers in whose case this hypothesis is exactly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: verified; and to the great majority it is not applicable at all. An
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: additional customer, to most dealers, is equivalent to an increase of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their productive capital. He enables them to convert a portion of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital which was lying idle (and which could never have become
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive in their hands until a customer was found) into wages and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instruments of production; and if we suppose that the commodity, unless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: bought by him, would not have found a purchaser for a year after, then
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all which a capital of that value can enable men to produce during a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: year, is clear gain--gain to the dealer, or producer, and to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourers whom he will employ, and thus (if no one sustains any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: corresponding loss) gain to the nation. The aggregate produce of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
