author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country for the succeeding year is, therefore, increased; not by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mere exchange, but by calling into activity a portion of the national
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, which, had it not been for the exchange, would have remained
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for some time longer unemployed.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Thus there are actually at all times producers and dealers, of all, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nearly all classes, whose capital is lying partially idle, because they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have not found the means of fulfilling the condition which the division
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of labour renders indispensable to the full employment of capital,--viz.,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that of exchanging their products with each other. If these persons
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: could find one another out, they could mutually relieve each other from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this disadvantage. Any two shopkeepers, in insufficient employment, who
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: agreed to deal at each other's shops so long as they could there
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchase articles of as good a quality as elsewhere, and at as low a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price, would render the nation a service. It may be said that they must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: previously have dealt, to the same amount, with some other dealers; but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this is erroneous, since they could only have obtained the means of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchasing by being previously enabled to sell. By their compact, each
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would gain a customer, who would call his capital into fuller employment;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: each therefore would obtain an increased produce; and they would thus be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enabled to become better customers to each other than they could be to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: third parties.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is obvious that every dealer who has not business sufficient fully to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employ his capital (which is the case with all dealers when they commence
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: business, and with many to the end of their lives), is in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: predicament simply for want of some one with whom to exchange his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities; and as there are such persons to about the same degree
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: probably in all trades, it is evident that if these persons sought one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another out, they have their remedy in their own hands, and by each
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other's assistance might bring their capital into more full employment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We are now qualified to define the exact nature of the benefit which a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producer or dealer derives from the acquisition of a new customer. It is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as follows:--
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 1. If any part of his own capital was locked up in the form of unsold
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: goods, producing (for a longer period or a shorter) nothing at all;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a portion of this is called into greater activity, and becomes more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: constantly productive. But to this we must add some further advantages.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2. If the additional demand exceeds what can be supplied by setting at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: liberty the capital which exists in the state of unsold goods; and if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the dealer has additional resources, which were productively invested
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (in the public funds, for instance), but not in his own trade; he is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enabled to obtain, on a portion of these, not mere interest, but profit,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and so to gain that difference between the rate of profit and the rate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of interest, which may be considered as "wages of superintendance."
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 3. If all the dealer's capital is employed in his own trade, and no part
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of it locked up as unsold goods, the new demand affords him additional
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: encouragement to save, by enabling his savings to yield him not merely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest, but profit; and if he does not choose to save (or until he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shall have saved), it enables him to carry on an additional business
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with borrowed capital, and so gain the difference between interest and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit, or, in other words, to receive wages of superintendance on a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: larger amount of capital.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, it will be found, is a complete account of all the gains which a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: dealer in any commodity can derive from an accession to the number of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those who deal with him: and it is evident to every one, that these
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantages are real and important, and that they are the cause which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: induces a dealer of any kind to desire an increase of his business.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It follows from these premises, that the arrival of a new unproductive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumer (living on his own means) in any place, be that place a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: village, a town, or an entire country, is beneficial to that place, if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it causes to any of the dealers of the place any of the advantages above
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enumerated, without withdrawing an equal advantage of the same kind from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any other dealer of the same place.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This accordingly is the test by which we must try all such questions,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and by which the propriety of the analogical argument, from dealing with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a tradesman to dealing with a nation, must be decided.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us take, for instance, as our example, Paris, which is much
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: frequented by strangers from various parts of the world, who, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sojourners there, live unproductively upon their means. Let us consider
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whether the presence of these persons is beneficial, in an _industrial_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: point of view, to Paris.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We exclude from the consideration that portion of the strangers' incomes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which they pay to natives as direct remuneration for service, or labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of any description. This is obviously beneficial to the country. An
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increase in the funds expended in employing labour, whether that labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be productive or unproductive, tends equally to raise wages. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: condition of the whole labouring class is, so far, benefited. It is true
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the labourers thus employed by sojourners are probably, in part or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: altogether, withdrawn from productive employment. But this is far from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: being an evil; for either the situation of the labouring classes is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: improved, which is far more than an equivalent for a diminution in mere
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production, or the rise of wages acts as a stimulus to population, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: then the number of productive labourers becomes as great as before.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To this we may add, that what the sojourners pay as wages of labour or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: service (whether constant or casual), though expended unproductively by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the first possessor, may, when it passes into the hands of the receivers,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be by them saved, and invested in a productive employment. If so, a direct
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: addition is made to the national capital.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: All this is obvious, and is sufficiently allowed by political economists;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who have invariably set apart the gains of all persons coming under the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: class of domestic servants, as real advantages arising to a place from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the residence there of an increased number of unproductive consumers.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have only to examine whether the purchases of commodities by these
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductive consumers, confer the same kind of benefit upon the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: village, town, or nation, which is bestowed upon a particular tradesman
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by dealing at his shop.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now it is obvious that the sojourners, on their arrival, confer the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: benefit in question upon some dealers, who did not enjoy it before. They
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchase their food, and many other articles, from the dealers in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place. They, therefore, call the capital of some dealers, which was
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: locked up in unsold goods, into more active employment. They encourage
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them to save, and enable them to receive wages of superintendance upon a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: larger amount of capital. These effects being undeniable, the question
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is, whether the presence of the sojourners deprives any others of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Paris dealers of a similar advantage.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It will be seen that it does; and nothing will then remain but a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comparison of the amounts.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is obvious to all who reflect (and was shown in the paper which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: precedes this) that the remittances to persons who expend their incomes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in foreign countries are, after a slight passage of the precious metals,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: defrayed in commodities: and that the result commonly is, an increase of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exports and a diminution of imports, until the latter fall short of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: former by the amount of the remittances.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The arrival, therefore, of the strangers (say from England), while it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: creates at Paris a market for commodities equivalent in value to their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: funds, displaces in the market other commodities to an equal value. To
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the extent of the increase of exports from England into France in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: way of remittance, it introduces additional commodities which, by their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cheapness, displace others formerly produced in that country. To the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: extent of the diminution of imports into England from France,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities which existed or which were habitually produced in that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country are deprived of a market, or can only find one at a price not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient to defray the cost.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It must, therefore, be a matter of mere accident, if by arriving in a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place, the new unproductive consumer causes any net advantage to its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: industry, of the kind which we are now examining. Not to mention that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: this, like any other change in the channels of trade, may render useless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a portion of fixed capital, and so far injure the national wealth.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: A distinction, however, must here be made.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The place to which the new unproductive consumers have come, may be a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: town or village, as well as a country. If a town or village, it may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: either be or not be a place having an export trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the place had no previous trade except with the immediate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: neighbourhood, there are no exports and imports, by the new arrangement
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of which, the remittance can be made. There is no capital, formerly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed in manufacturing for the foreign market, which is now brought
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: into less full employment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Yet the remittance evidently is still made in commodities, but in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: case without displacing any which were produced before. To shew this, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is necessary to make the following remarks.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The reason why towns exist, is that _ceteris paribus_ it is convenient,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in order to save cost of carriage, that the production of commodities
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: should take place as far as practicable in the immediate vicinity of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumer. Capital finds its way so easily from town to country and from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country to town, that the amount of capital in the town will be regulated
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wholly by the amount which can be employed there more conveniently than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: elsewhere. Consequently the capital of a place will be such as is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 1st. To produce all commodities which from local circumstances can be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produced there at less cost than elsewhere: and if this be the case to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any great extent, it will be an exporting town. When we say _produced_,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: we may add, or _stored_.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2nd. To produce and retail the commodities which are consumed by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inhabitants of the town, and the place of whose production is in other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: respects a matter of indifference. To the inhabitants of the town must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be added such dwellers in the adjoining country, as are nearer to that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place than to any other equally well furnished market.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now, if new unproductive consumers resort to the place, it is clear that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for the latter of these two purposes, more capital will be required than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: before. Consequently, if less is not required for the former purpose,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more capital will establish itself at the place.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Until this additional capital has arrived, the producers and dealers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: already on the spot will enjoy great advantages. Every particle of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own capital will be called into the most active employment. What their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital does not enable them to supply, will be got from others at a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distance, who cannot supply it on such favourable terms; consequently
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they will be in the predicament of possessing a partial monopoly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: --receiving for every thing a price regulated by a higher cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production than they are compelled to pay. They also, being in possession
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the market, will be enabled to make a large portion of the new capital
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: pass through their hands, and thus to earn wages of superintendance upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If, indeed, the place from whence the strangers came, previously traded
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with that where they have taken up their abode, the effect of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: arrival is, that the exports of the town will diminish, and that it will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be supplied from abroad with something which it previously produced at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: home. In this way an amount of capital will be set free equal to that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: required, and there will be no increase on the whole. The removal of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: court from London to Birmingham would not necessarily, though it would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: probably [6], increase the amount of capital in the latter place. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: afflux of money to Birmingham, and its efflux from London, would render
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it cheaper to make some articles in London for Birmingham consumption;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and to make others in London for home consumption, which were formerly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: brought from Birmingham.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But instead of Birmingham, an exporting town, suppose a village, or a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: town which only produced and retailed for itself and its immediate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: vicinity. The remittances must come thither in the shape of money; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: though the money would not remain, but would be sent away in exchange
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for commodities, it would, however, first pass through the hands of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producers and dealers in the place, and would by them be exported in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exchange for the articles which they require--viz. the materials, tools,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and subsistence necessary for the increased production now required of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them, and articles of foreign luxury for their own increased unproductive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumption. These articles would not displace any formerly made in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place, but on the contrary, would forward the production of more.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Hence we may consider the following propositions as established:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 1. The expenditure of absentees (the case of domestic servants excepted,)
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is not necessarily any loss to the _country_ which they leave, or gain to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the _country_ which they resort to (save in the manner shown in Essay I.):
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for almost every _country_ habitually exports and imports to a much
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater value than the incomes of its absentees, or of the foreign
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sojourners within it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2. But sojourners often do much good to the _town_ or village which they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: resort to, and absentees harm to that which they leave. The capital of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the petty tradesman in a small town near an absentee's estate, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: deprived of the market for which it is conveniently situated, and must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: resort to another to which other capitals lie nearer, and where it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequently outbid, and gains less; obtaining only the same price, with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater expenses. But this evil would be equally occasioned, if, instead
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of going abroad, the absentee had removed to his own capital city.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the tradesman could, in the latter case, remove to the metropolis, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the former, employ himself in producing increased exports, or in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producing for home consumption articles now no longer imported, each in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the place most convenient for that operation; he would not be a loser,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: though the place which he was obliged to leave might be said to lose.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Paris undoubtedly gains much by the sojourn of foreigners, while the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: counteracting loss by diminution of exports from France is suffered by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the great trading and manufacturing towns, Rouen, Bordeaux, Lyons, &c,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which also suffer the principal part of the loss by importation of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: articles previously produced at home. The capital thus set free, finds
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its most convenient seat to be Paris, since the business to which it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must turn is the production of articles to be unproductively consumed by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the sojourners.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The great trading towns of France would undoubtedly be more flourishing,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: if France were not frequented by foreigners.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Rome and Naples are perhaps purely benefited by the foreigners
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sojourning there: for they have so little external trade, that their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: case may resemble that of the village in our hypothesis.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Absenteeism, therefore, (except as shown in the first Essay,) is a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: local, not a national evil; and the resort of foreigners, in so far as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they purchase for unproductive consumption, is not, in any commercial
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country, a national, though it may be a local good.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: From the considerations which we have now adduced, it is obvious what
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is meant by such phrases as a _brisk demand_, and a rapid circulation.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There is a brisk demand and a rapid circulation, when goods, generally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: speaking, are sold as fast as they can be produced. There is slackness,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: on the contrary, and stagnation, when goods, which have been produced,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remain for a long time unsold. In the former case, the capital which has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been locked up in production is disengaged as soon as the production is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: completed; and can be immediately employed in further production. In the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: latter case, a large portion of the productive capital of the country is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: lying in temporary inactivity.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: From what has been already said, it is obvious that periods of "brisk
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand" are also the periods of greatest production: the national
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital is never called into full employment but at those periods. This,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: however, is no reason for desiring such times; it is not desirable that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the whole capital of the country should be in full employment. For, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: calculations of producers and traders being of necessity imperfect,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there are always some commodities which are more or less in excess, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there are always some which are in deficiency. If, therefore, the whole
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: truth were known, there would always be some classes of producers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: contracting, not extending, their operations. If _all_ are endeavouring
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to extend them, it is a certain proof that some general delusion is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: afloat. The commonest cause of such delusion is some general, or very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: extensive, rise of prices (whether caused by speculation or by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: currency) which persuades all dealers that they are growing rich. And
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hence, an increase of production really takes place during the progress
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of depreciation, as long as the existence of depreciation is not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: suspected; and it is this which gives to the fallacies of the currency
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: school, principally represented by Mr. Attwood, all the little
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: plausibility they possess. But when the delusion vanishes and the truth
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is disclosed, those whose commodities are relatively in excess must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminish their production or be ruined: and if during the high prices
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they have built mills and erected machinery, they will be likely to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: repent at leisure.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In the present state of the commercial world, mercantile transactions
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: being carried on upon an immense scale, but the remote causes of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fluctuations in prices being very little understood, so that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unreasonable hopes and unreasonable fears alternately rule with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tyrannical sway over the minds of a majority of the mercantile public;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general eagerness to buy and general reluctance to buy, succeed one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another in a manner more or less marked, at brief intervals. Except
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: during short periods of transition, there is almost always either great
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: briskness of business or great stagnation; either the principal
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producers of almost all the leading articles of industry have as many
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: orders as they can possibly execute, or the dealers in almost all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities have their warehouses full of unsold goods.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In this last ease, it is commonly said that there is a general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superabundance; and as those economists who have contested the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possibility of general superabundance, would none of them deny the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possibility or even the frequent occurrence of the phenomenon which we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have just noticed, it would seem incumbent on them to show, that the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expression to which they object is not applicable to a state of things
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in which all or most commodities remain unsold, in the same sense in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which there is said to be a superabundance of any one commodity when it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remains in the warehouses of dealers for want of a market.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This is merely a question of naming, but an important one, as it seems
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to us that much apparent difference of opinion has been produced by a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mere difference in the mode of describing the same facts, and that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: persons who at bottom were perfectly agreed, have considered each other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as guilty of gross error, and sometimes oven misrepresentation, on this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subject.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In order to afford the explanations, with which it is necessary to take
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the doctrine of the impossibility of an excess of all commodities, we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must advert for a moment to the argument by which this impossibility is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commonly maintained.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There can never, it is said, be a want of buyers for all commodities;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because whoever offers a commodity for sale, desires to obtain a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodity in exchange for it, and is therefore a buyer by the mere fact
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of his being a seller. The sellers and the buyers, for all commodities
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: taken together, must, by the metaphysical necessity of the case, be an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exact equipoise to each other; and if there be more sellers than buyers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of one thing, there must be more buyers than sellers for another.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This argument is evidently founded on the supposition of a state of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: barter; and, on that supposition, it is perfectly incontestable. When
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: two persons perform an act of barter, each of them is at once a seller
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and a buyer. He cannot sell without buying. Unless he chooses to buy
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some other person's commodity, he does not sell his own.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If, however, we suppose that money is used, these propositions cease to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be exactly true. It must be admitted that no person desires money for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its own sake, (unless some very rare cases of misers be an exception,)
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and that he who sells his commodity, receiving money in exchange, does
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: so with the intention of buying with that same money some other commodity.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Interchange by means of money is therefore, as has been often observed,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ultimately nothing but barter. But there is this difference--that in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: case of barter, the selling and the buying are simultaneously confounded
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in one operation; you sell what you have, and buy what you want, by one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indivisible act, and you cannot do the one without doing the other. Now
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the effect of the employment of money, and even the utility of it, is,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that it enables this one act of interchange to be divided into two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: separate acts or operations; one of which may be performed now, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other a year hence, or whenever it shall be most convenient. Although he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who sells, really sells only to buy, he needs not buy at the same moment
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: when he sells; and he does not therefore necessarily add to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _immediate_ demand for one commodity when he adds to the supply of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another. The buying and selling being now separated, it may very well
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: occur, that there may be, at some given time, a very general inclination
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to sell with as little delay as possible, accompanied with an equally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general inclination to defer all purchases as long as possible. This is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: always actually the case, in those periods which are described as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: periods of general excess. And no one, after sufficient explanation,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will contest the possibility of general excess, in this sense of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: word. The state of things which we have just described, and which is of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no uncommon occurrence, amounts to it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: For when there is a general anxiety to sell, and a general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disinclination to buy, commodities of all kinds remain for a long time
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unsold, and those which find an immediate market, do so at a very low
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: price. If it be said that when all commodities fall in price, the fall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is of no consequence, since mere money price is not material while the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: relative value of all commodities remains the same, we answer that this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be true if the low prices were to last for ever. But as it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: certain that prices will rise again sooner or later, the person who is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obliged by necessity to sell his commodity at a low money price is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: really a sufferer, the money he receives sinking shortly to its ordinary
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: value. Every person, therefore, delays selling if he can, keeping his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital unproductive in the mean time, and sustaining the consequent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: loss of interest. There is stagnation to those who are not obliged to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sell, and distress to those who are.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is true that this state can be only temporary, and must even be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: succeeded by a reaction of corresponding violence, since those who have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sold without buying will certainly buy at last, and there will then be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more buyers than sellers. But although the general over-supply is of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessity only temporary, this is no more than may be said of every
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: partial over-supply. An overstocked state of the market is always
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: temporary, and is generally followed by a more than common briskness of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In order to render the argument for the impossibility of an excess of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all commodities applicable to the case in which a circulating medium is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed, money must itself be considered as a commodity. It must,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: undoubtedly, be admitted that there cannot be an excess of all other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities, and an excess of money at the same time.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But those who have, at periods such as we have described, affirmed that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there was an excess of all commodities, never pretended that money was
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one of these commodities; they held that there was not an excess, but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a deficiency of the circulating medium. What they called a general
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superabundance, was not a superabundance of commodities relatively to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities, but a superabundance of all commodities relatively to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money. What it amounted to was, that persons in general, at that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: particular time, from a general expectation of being called upon to meet
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sudden demands, liked better to possess money than any other commodity.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Money, consequently, was in request, and all other commodities were in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comparative disrepute. In extreme cases, money is collected in masses,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and hoarded; in the milder cases, people merely defer parting with their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money, or coming under any new engagements to part with it. But the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: result is, that all commodities fall in price, or become unsaleable.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When this happens to one single commodity, there is said to be a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superabundance of that commodity; and if that be a proper expression,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there would seem to be in the nature of the case no particular
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: impropriety in saying that there is a superabundance of all or most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities, when all or most of them are in this same predicament.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is, however, of the utmost importance to observe that excess of all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities, in the only sense in which it is possible, means only a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: temporary fall in their value relatively to money. To suppose that the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: markets for all commodities could, in any other sense than this, be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: overstocked, involves the absurdity that commodities may fall in value
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: relatively to themselves; or that, of two commodities, each can fall
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: relatively to the other, A becoming equivalent to B-_x_, and B to A-_x_,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at the same time. And it is, perhaps, a sufficient reason for not using
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: phrases of this description, that they suggest the idea of excessive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production. A want of market for one article may arise from excessive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production of that article; but when commodities in general become
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unsaleable, it is from a very different cause; there cannot be excessive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production of commodities in general.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The argument against the possibility of general over-production is quite
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conclusive, so far as it applies to the doctrine that a country may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulate capital too fast; that produce in general may, by increasing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: faster than the demand for it, reduce all producers to distress. This
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proposition, strange to say, was almost a received doctrine as lately as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thirty years ago; and the merit of those who have exploded it is much
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater than might be inferred from the extreme obviousness of its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: absurdity when it is stated in its native simplicity. It is true that if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all the wants of all the inhabitants of a country were fully satisfied,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no further capital could find useful employment; but, in that case, none
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be accumulated. So long as there remain any persons not possessed,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: we do not say of subsistence, but of the most refined luxuries, and who
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would work to possess them, there is employment for capital; and if the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodities which these persons want are not produced and placed at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their disposal, it can only be because capital does not exist, disposable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for the purpose of employing, if not any other labourers, those very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourers themselves, in producing the articles for their own consumption.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Nothing can be more chimerical than the fear that the accumulation of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital should produce poverty and not wealth, or that it will ever take
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place too fast for its own end. Nothing is more true than that it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce which constitutes the market for produce, and that every increase
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of production, if distributed without miscalculation among all kinds of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce in the proportion which private interest would dictate, creates,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or rather constitutes, its own demand.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This is the truth which the deniers of general over-production have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: seized and enforced; nor is it pretended that anything has been added
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to it, or subtracted from it, in the present disquisition. But it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thought that those who receive the doctrine accompanied with the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: explanations which we have given, will understand, more clearly than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: before, what is, and what is not, implied in it; and will see that, when
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: properly understood, it in no way contradicts those obvious facts which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are universally known and admitted to be not only of possible, but of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: actual and even frequent occurrence. The doctrine in question only
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: appears a paradox, because it has usually been so expressed as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: apparently to contradict these well-known facts; which, however, were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equally well known to the authors of the doctrine, who, therefore, can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: only have adopted from inadvertence any form of expression which could
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to a candid person appear inconsistent with it. The essentials of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: doctrine are preserved when it is allowed that there cannot be permanent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: excess of production, or of accumulation; though it be at the same time
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: admitted, that as there may be a temporary excess of any one article
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: considered separately, so may there of commodities generally, not in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequence of over-production, but of a want of commercial confidence.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: NOTE:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: [6] Probably; because most articles of an ornamental description being
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: still required from the same makers, these makers, with their capital,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It would probably be difficult to point out any two words, respecting
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than they have been concerning the two words _productive_ and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _unproductive_; whether considered as applied to _labour_, to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: _consumption_, or to _expenditure_.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Although this is a question solely of nomenclature, it is one of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient importance to be worth another attempt to settle it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: satisfactorily. For, although writers on political economy have not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: agreed in the ideas which they were accustomed to annex to these terms,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the terms have generally been employed to denote ideas of very great
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: importance, and it is impossible that some vagueness should not have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been thrown upon the ideas themselves by looseness in the use of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: words by which they are habitually designated. Further, so long as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: pedantic objection to the introduction of new technical terms continues,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accurate thinkers on moral and political subjects are limited to a very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: scanty vocabulary for the expression of their ideas. It therefore is of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: great importance that the words with which mankind are familiar, should
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be turned to the greatest possible advantage as instruments of thought;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that one word should not be used as the sign of an idea which is already
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: required to denote ideas of great importance, should not be usurped for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the expression of such as are comparatively insignificant.
