author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The phrases _productive labour_, and _productive consumption_, have been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed by some writers on political economy with very great latitude.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: They have considered, and classed, as productive labour and productive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumption, all labour which serves any _useful_ purpose--all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumption which is not _waste_. Mr. M'Culloch has asserted, _totidem
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: verbis_, that the labour of Madame Pasta was as well entitled to be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: called productive labour as that of a cotton spinner.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Employed in this sense, the words _productive_ and _unproductive_ are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all the ideas to which the words _productive_ and _unproductive_ are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: here applied.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This use of the terms, therefore, is subversive of the ends of language.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: here the words productive and unproductive have been affected with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sacrifice; together with all such things as, though produced by labour,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are not held in sufficient general estimation to command any price in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the market.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exclusively to what is allowed to be production: the one was equally

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: to the acquired skill of those who are acknowledged to be productive

text: labourers, is a purely arbitrary division, and does not conduce to the

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The classes themselves may be, mentally speaking, perfectly definite,

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: should be placed, if the classification be properly made, and properly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expressed, the uncertainty can turn only upon a matter of fact. It is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: uncertain to which class the object belongs, because it is doubtful
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: class or those of the other. But the characteristics themselves may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: defined and distinguished with the nicest exactness, and always ought to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the two classes, does not happen to be of any particular consequence.

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is frequently said that classification is a mere affair of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: convenience. This assertion is true in one sense, but not if its meaning
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be, that the most proper classification is that in which it is easiest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to say whether an object belongs to one class or to the other. The use
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: among things; and that is the best classification, which is founded upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the most important distinctions, whatever be the facilities which it may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: afford of ticketing and arranging the different objects which exist in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductive, we ought to endeavour to render them significative of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: most important distinctions which, without too glaring a violation of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: received usage, they can be made to express.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We ought further, when we are restricted to the employment of old words,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to endeavour as far as possible that it shall not be necessary to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: struggle against the old associations with those words. We should, if
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possible, give the words such a meaning, that the propositions in which

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: people are accustomed to use them, shall as far as possible still be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: true; and that the feelings habitually excited by them, shall be such as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the things to which we mean to appropriate them ought to excite.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: In whatever manner political economists may have settled the definition

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: impoverished. Productive expenditure they are accustomed to view as

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a gain; unproductive expenditure, however useful, as a sacrifice.

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productively, they always characterise as a squandering of resources,

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us then examine what qualities in expenditure, and in the employment
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: really flow.

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: the permanent sources of enjoyment in the country might have been not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminished but increased.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The performer on the musical instrument then is, so far as respects that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: act, not a productive, but an unproductive labourer. But what shall we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: say of the workman who made the musical instrument? He, most persons
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would say, is a productive labourer; and with reason; because the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: musical instrument is a permanent source of enjoyment, which does not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: begin and end with the enjoying, and therefore admits of being
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulated.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But the _skill_ of the musician is a permanent source of enjoyment, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: well as the instrument which he plays upon: and although skill is not a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: material object, but a quality of an object, viz., of the hands and mind
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the performer; nevertheless skill possesses exchangeable value, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: acquired by labour and capital, and is capable of being stored and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulated. Skill, therefore, must be considered as wealth; and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour and funds employed in acquiring skill in anything tending to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advantage or pleasure of mankind, must be considered to be productively
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed and expended.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The skill of a productive labourer is analogous to the machinery he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: works with: neither of them is enjoyment, nor conduces directly to it,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but both conduce indirectly to it, and both in the same way. If a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: spinning-jenny be wealth, the spinner's skill is also wealth. If the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mechanic who made the spinning-jenny laboured productively, the spinner
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: also laboured productively when he was learning his trade: and what they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: both consumed was consumed productively, that is to say, its consumption
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: did not tend to diminish, but to increase the sum of the permanent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sources of enjoyment in the country, by effecting a new creation of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those sources, more than equal to the amount of the consumption.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The skill of a tailor, and the implements he employs, contribute in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: same way to the convenience of him who wears the coat, namely, a remote
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: way: it is the coat itself which contributes immediately. The skill of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Madame Pasta, and the building and decorations which aid the effect of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: her performance, contribute in the same way to the enjoyment of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: audience, namely, an immediate way, without any intermediate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instrumentality. The building and decorations are consumed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductively, and Madame Pasta labours and consumes unproductively;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for the building is used and worn out, and Madame Pasta performs,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: immediately for the spectators' enjoyment, and without leaving, as a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequence of the performance, any permanent result possessing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exchangeable value: consequently the epithet unproductive must be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equally applied to the gradual wearing out of the bricks and mortar, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nightly consumption of the more perishable "properties" of the theatre,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the labour of Madame Pasta in acting, and of the orchestra in playing.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But notwithstanding this, the architect who built the theatre was a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive labourer; so were the producers of the perishable articles;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: so were those who constructed the musical instruments; and so, we must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be permitted to add, were those who instructed the musicians, and all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: persons who, by the instructions which they may have given to Madame
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Pasta, contributed to the formation of her talent. All these persons
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: contributed to the enjoyment of the audience in the same way, and that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a remote way, viz., by the production of a _permanent source of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment_.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The difference between this case, and the case of the cotton spinner
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: already adverted to, is this. The spinning-jenny, and the skill of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cotton spinner, are not only the result of productive labour, but are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: themselves productively consumed. The musical instrument and the skill
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the musician are equally the result of productive labour, but are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: themselves unproductively consumed.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us now consider what kinds of labour, and of consumption or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expenditure, will be classed as productive, and what as unproductive,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: according to this rule.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The following are always productive:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour and expenditure, of which the direct object or effect is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: creation of some material product useful or agreeable to mankind.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour and expenditure, of which the direct effect and object are, to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: endow human or other animated beings with faculties or qualities useful
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or agreeable to mankind, and possessing exchangeable value.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour and expenditure, which without having for their direct object the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: creation of any useful material product or bodily or mental faculty or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quality, yet tend indirectly to promote one or other of those ends, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are exerted or incurred solely for that purpose.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The following are partly productive and partly unproductive, and cannot
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with propriety be ranged decidedly with either class:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour or expenditure which does indeed create, or promote the creation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of, some useful material product or bodily or mental faculty or quality,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but which is not incurred or exerted for that sole end; having also for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another, and perhaps its principal end, enjoyment, or the promotion of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Such are the labour of the judge, the legislator, the police-officer,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the soldier; and the expenditure incurred for their support. These
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: functionaries protect and secure mankind in the exclusive possession of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: such material products or acquired faculties as belong to them; and by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the security which they so confer, they indirectly increase production
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in a degree far more than equivalent to the expense which is necessary
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for their maintenance. But this is not the only purpose for which they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exist; they protect mankind, not merely in the possession of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: permanent resources, but also in their actual enjoyments; and so far,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: although highly useful, they cannot, conformably to the distinction
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which we have attempted to lay down, be considered productive labourers.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Such, also, are the labour and the wages of domestic servants. Such
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: persons are entertained mainly as subservient to mere enjoyment; but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: most of them occasionally, and some habitually, render services which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must be considered as of a productive nature; such as that of cookery,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the last stage in the manufacture of food; or gardening, a branch of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: agriculture.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The following are wholly unproductive:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour exerted, and expenditure incurred, directly and exclusively for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the purpose of enjoyment, and not calling into existence anything,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whether substance or quality, but such as begins and perishes in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour exerted and expenditure incurred uselessly, or in pure waste, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: yielding neither direct enjoyment nor permanent sources of enjoyment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It may be objected, that expenditure incurred even for pure enjoyment
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: promotes production indirectly, by inciting to exertion. Thus the view
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the splendour of a rich establishment is supposed by some writers to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce upon the mind of an indigent spectator an earnest desire of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoying the same luxuries, and a consequent purpose of working with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: vigour and diligence, and saving from his earnings, thus increasing the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive capital of the country.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is true that mankind are, for the most part, excited to productive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: industry solely by the desire of subsequently consuming the result of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their labour and accumulation. The consumption called unproductive,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: viz., that of which the direct result is enjoyment, is in reality the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: end, to which production is only the means; and a desire for the end,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is what alone impels any one to have recourse to the means.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But, notwithstanding this, it is of the greatest importance to mark the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distinction between the labour and the consumption which have enjoyment
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for their immediate end, and the labour and the consumption of which the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: immediate end is reproduction. Though the sight of the former may still
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: further stimulate that desire for the enjoyments afforded by wealth,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the mere knowledge, without the immediate view, would suffice to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: excite (and without dwelling on the consideration that if the example
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a large expenditure excites one individual to accumulation, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: encourages two to prodigal expense); still, if we look only to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: effects which are intended, or to those which immediately follow from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the consumption, and whose connexion with it can be distinctly traced,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it evidently renders a country poorer in the permanent sources of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment; while reproductive consumption leaves the country richer in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: these same sources. Besides, if what is spent for mere pleasure promotes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indirectly the increase of wealth, it can only be by inducing others
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _not_ to expend on mere pleasure.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Before quitting the subject, one more observation should be added. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must not be supposed that what is expended upon unproductive labourers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is necessarily, the whole of it, unproductively consumed. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductive labourers may save part of their wages, and invest them in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a productive employment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is not unusual to speak of what is paid in wages to a labourer as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: being thereby _consumed_, as if all profit and loss to the nation were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to be seen in the capitalist's account-book. What is paid for productive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour is said to be productively consumed; what is paid for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductive labour is said to be consumed unproductively. It would be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proper to say, not that it is productively or unproductively _consumed_,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but productively or unproductively _expended_; otherwise, we shall be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obliged to say that it is consumed twice over; the first time
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductively, perhaps, and the second, it may be, productively.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To pronounce in which way the wages of the labourer are consumed, we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: must follow them into the labourer's own hands. As much as is necessary
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to keep the productive labourer in perfect health and fitness for his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employment, may be said to be consumed productively. To this should be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: added what he expends in rearing children to the age at which they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: become capable of productive industry. If the state of the market for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour be such as to afford him more, this he may either save, or, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the common expression is, he may spend it. If he saves any portion, this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (unless it be merely hoarded) he intends to employ productively, and it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will be productively consumed. If he spends it, the consumption is for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: enjoyment immediately, and is therefore unproductive.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This suggests another correction in the established language. Political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: economists generally define the "net produce" to be that portion of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gross annual produce of a country which remains after replacing the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital annually consumed. This, as they proceed to explain, consists of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits and rent; wages being included in the other portion of the gross
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce, that which goes to replace capital. After this definition, they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: usually proceed to tell us that the net produce, and that alone,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: constitutes the fund from which a nation can accumulate, and add to its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, as also that which it can, without retrograding in wealth,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expend unproductively, or for enjoyment. Now, it is impossible that both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the above propositions can be true. If the net produce is that which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remains after replacing capital, then net produce is not the only fund
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: out of which accumulation may be made: for accumulation may be made from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages; this is in all countries one of the great sources, and in countries
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: like America perhaps the greatest source of accumulation. If, on the other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hand, it is desirable to reserve the name of net produce to denote the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fund available for accumulation or for unproductive consumption, we must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: define net produce differently. The definition which appears the best
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: adapted to render the ordinary doctrines relating to net produce true,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be this:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The net produce of a country is whatever is annually produced beyond
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: what is necessary for maintaining the stock of materials and implements
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unimpaired, for keeping all productive labourers alive and in condition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for work, and for just keeping up their numbers without increase. What
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is required for these purposes, or, in other words, for keeping up the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive resources of the country, cannot be diverted from its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: destination without rendering the nation as a whole poorer. But all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which is produced beyond this, whether it be in the hands of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourer, of the capitalist, or of any of the numerous varieties of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rent-owners, may be taken for immediate enjoyment, without prejudice to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the productive resources of the community; and whatever part of it is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not so taken, constitutes a clear addition to the national capital, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the permanent sources of enjoyment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ESSAY IV.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ON PROFITS, AND INTEREST.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The profits of stock are the surplus which remains to the capitalist
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: after replacing his capital: and the ratio which that surplus bears to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the capital itself, is the _rate_ of profit.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This being the definition of profits, it might seem natural to adopt, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a sufficient theory in regard to the rate of profit, that it depends
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon the productive power of capital. Some countries are favoured beyond
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: others, either by nature or art, in the means of production. If the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: powers of the soil, or of machinery, enable capital to produce what is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessary for replacing itself, and twenty per cent more, profits will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be twenty per cent; and so on.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, accordingly, is a popular mode of speaking on the subject of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits; but it has only the semblance, not the reality, of an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: explanation. The "productive power of capital," though a common, and,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for some purposes, a convenient expression, is a delusive one. Capital,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: strictly speaking, has no productive power. The only productive power is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that of labour; assisted, no doubt, by tools, and acting upon materials.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: That portion of capital which consists of tools and materials, may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: said, perhaps, without any great impropriety, to have a productive
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: power, because they contribute, along with labour, to the accomplishment
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of production. But that portion of capital which consists of wages, has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no productive power of its own. Wages have no productive power; they are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the price of a productive power. Wages do not contribute, along with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour, to the production of commodities, no more than the price of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tools contributes along with the tools themselves. If labour could be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: had without purchase, wages might be dispensed with. That portion of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital which is expended in the wages of labour, is only the means by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the capitalist procures to himself, in the way of purchase, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: use of that labour in which the power of production really resides.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The proper view of capital is, that anything whatever, which a person
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possesses, constitutes his capital, provided he is able, and intends,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to employ it, not in consumption for the purpose of enjoyment, but in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possessing himself of the means of production, with the intention of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employing those means productively. Now the means of production are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour, implements, and materials. The only productive power which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: anywhere exists, is the productive power of labour, implements, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: materials.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We need not, on this account, altogether proscribe the expression,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: "productive power of capital;" but we should carefully note, that it can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: only mean the quantity of real productive power which the capitalist,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by means of his capital, can command. This may change, though the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive power of labour remains the same. Wages, for example, may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rise; and then, although all the circumstances of production remain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exactly as they were before, the same capital will yield a less return,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because it will set in motion a less quantity of productive labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We may, therefore, consider the capital of a producer as measured by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: means which he has of possessing himself of the different essentials of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production: namely, labour, and the various articles which labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: requires as materials, or of which it avails itself as aids.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The ratio between the price which he has to pay for these means of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production, and the produce which they enable him to raise, is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _rate_ of his _profit_. If he must give for labour and tools four-fifths
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of what they will produce, the remaining fifth will constitute his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit, and will give him a rate of one in four, or twenty-five per
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cent, on his outlay.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is necessary here to remark, what cannot indeed by any possibility be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: misunderstood, but might possibly be overlooked in cases where attention
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to it is indispensable, viz., that we are speaking now of the _rate_ of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit, not the gross profit. If the capital of the country is very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: great, a profit of only five per cent upon it may be much more ample,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: may support a much larger number of capitalists and their families in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: much greater affluence, than a profit of twenty-five per cent on the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comparatively small capital of a poor country. The _gross_ profit of a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country is the actual amount of necessaries, conveniences, and luxuries,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which are divided among its capitalists: but whether this be large or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: small, the rate of profit may be just the same. The rate of profit is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the proportion which the profit bears to the capital; which the surplus
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce after replacing the outlay, bears to the outlay. In short, if we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: compare the _price paid_ for labour and tools with what that labour and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those tools will _produce_, from this ratio we may calculate the rate of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: As the gross profit may be very different though the rate of profit be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same; so also may the absolute price paid for labour and tools be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: very different, and yet the proportion between the price paid and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce obtained may be just the same. For greater clearness, let us
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: omit, for the present, the consideration of tools, materials, &c, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conceive production as the result solely of labour. In a certain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country, let us suppose, the wages of each labourer are one quarter of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wheat per year, and 100 men can produce, in one year, 120 quarters. Here
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the price paid for labour is to the produce of that labour as 100 to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 120, and profits are 20 per cent. Suppose now that, in another country,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages are just double what they are in the country before supposed;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: namely, two quarters of wheat per year, for each labourer. But suppose,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: likewise, that the productive power of labour is double what it is in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the first country; that by the greater fertility of the soil, 100 men
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: can produce 240 quarters, instead of 120 as before. Here it is obvious,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the real price paid for labour is twice as great in the one country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as in the other; but the produce being also twice as great, the ratio
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: between the price of labour and the produce of labour is still exactly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same: an outlay of 200 quarters gives a return of 240 quarters, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits, as before, are 20 per cent.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Profits, then (meaning not gross profits, but the rate of profit),
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: depend (not upon the price of labour, tools, and materials--but) upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the ratio between the price of labour, tools, and materials, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce of them: upon the proportionate share of the produce of industry
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which it is necessary to offer, in order to purchase that industry and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the means of setting it in motion.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have hitherto spoken of tools, buildings, and materials, as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: essentials of production, co-ordinate with labour, and equally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indispensable with it. This is true; but it is also true that tools,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: buildings, and materials, are themselves the produce of labour; and that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the only cause (cases of monopoly excepted) of their having any value,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is the labour which is required for their production.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If tools, buildings, and materials were the spontaneous gifts of nature,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: requiring no labour either in order to produce or to appropriate them;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and if they were thus bestowed upon mankind in indefinite quantity, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: without the possibility of being monopolized; they would still be as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: useful, as indispensable as they now are; but since they could, like air
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and the light of the sun, be obtained without cost or sacrifice, they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would form no part of the expenses of production, and no portion of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce would be required to be set aside in order to replace the outlay
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: made for these purposes. The whole produce, therefore, after replacing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the wages of labour, would be clear profit to the capitalist.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Labour alone is the primary means of production; "the original
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: purchase-money which has been paid for everything." Tools and materials,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: like other things, have originally cost nothing but labour; and have a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: value in the market only because wages have been paid for them. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour employed in making the tools and materials being added to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour afterwards employed in working up the materials by aid of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tools, the sum total gives the whole of the labour employed in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production of the completed commodity. In the ultimate analysis,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, labour appears to be the only essential of production. To
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: replace capital, is to replace nothing but the wages of the labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed. Consequently, the whole of the surplus, after replacing wages,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is profits. From this it seems to follow, that the ratio between the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages of labour and the produce of that labour gives the rate of profit.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: And thus we arrive at Mr. Ricardo's principle, that profits depend upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages; rising as wages fall, and falling as wages rise.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To protect this proposition (the most perfect form in which the law of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits seems to have been yet exhibited) against misapprehension, one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or two explanatory remarks are required.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If by wages, be meant what constitutes the real affluence of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourer, the _quantity_ of produce which he receives in exchange for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his labour; the proposition that profits vary inversely as wages, will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be obviously false. The rate of profit (as has been already observed and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exemplified) does not depend upon the price of labour, but upon the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion between the price of labour and the produce of it. If the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce of labour is large, the price of labour may also be large
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: without any diminution of the rate of profit: and, in fact, the rate of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit is highest in those countries (as, for instance, North America)
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: where the labourer is most largely remunerated. For the wages of labour,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: though so large, bear a less proportion to the abundant _produce_ of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour, there than elsewhere.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But this does not affect the truth of Mr. Ricardo's principle as he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: himself understood it; because an increase of the labourer's real
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comforts was not considered by him as a rise of wages. In his language
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages were only said to rise, when they rose not in mere quantity but in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _value_. To the labourer himself (he would have said) the _quantity_ of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his remuneration is the important circumstance: but its _value_ is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: only thing of importance to the person who purchases his labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The rate of profits depends not upon absolute or real wages, but upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the _value_ of wages.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If, however, by value, Mr. Ricardo had meant _exchangeable_ value, his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proposition would still have been remote from the truth. Profits depend
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no more upon the exchangeable value of the labourer's remuneration, than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon its quantity. The truth is, that by the exchangeable value is meant
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the quantity of commodities which the labourer can purchase with his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages; so that when we say the exchangeable value of wages, we say their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quantity, under another name.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Mr. Ricardo, however, did not use the word value in the sense of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exchangeable value.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Occasionally, in his writings, he could not avoid using the word as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other people use it, to denote value in exchange. But he more frequently
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed it in a sense peculiar to himself, to denote cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production; in other words, the _quantity of labour_ required to produce
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the article; that being his criterion of cost of production. Thus, if a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hat could be made with ten days' labour in France and with five days'
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour in England, he said that the value of a hat was double in France
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of what it was in England. If a quarter of corn could be produced a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: century ago with half as much labour as is necessary at present, Mr.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Ricardo said that the value of a quarter of corn had doubled.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Mr. Ricardo, therefore, would not have said that wages had risen,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because a labourer could obtain two pecks of flour instead of one, for a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: day's labour; but if last year he received, for a day's labour,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: something which required eight hours' labour to produce it, and this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: year something which requires nine hours, then Mr. Ricardo would say
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that wages had risen. A rise of wages, with Mr. Ricardo, meant an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increase in the cost of production of wages; an increase in the number
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of hours' labour which go to produce the wages of a day's labour; an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increase in the _proportion_ of the fruits of labour which the labourer
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receives for his own share; an increase in the ratio between the wages
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of his labour and the produce of it. This is the theory: the reasoning,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of which it is the result, has been given in the preceding paragraphs.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Some of Mr. Ricardo's followers, or more properly, of those who have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: adopted in most particulars the views of political economy which his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: genius was the first to open up, have given explanations of Mr.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Ricardo's doctrine to nearly the same effect as the above, but in rather
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: different terms. They have said that profits depend not on _absolute_,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but on _proportional_ wages: which they expounded to mean the proportion
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the labourers _en masse_ receive of the total produce of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It seems, however, to be rather an unusual and inconvenient use of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: language to speak of anything as depending upon the wages of labour, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: then to explain that by wages of labour you do not mean the wages of an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: individual labourer, but of all the labourers in the country
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: collectively. Mankind will never agree to call anything a rise of wages,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: except a rise of the wages of individual labourers, and it is therefore
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: preferable to employ language tending to fix attention upon the wages of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the individual. The wages, however, on which profits are said to depend,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are undoubtedly _proportional_ wages, namely, the proportional wages of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one labourer: that is, the ratio between the wages of one labourer, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (not the whole produce of the country, but) the amount of what one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourer can produce; the amount of that portion of the collective
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce of the industry of the country, which may be considered as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: corresponding to the labour of one single labourer. Proportional wages,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thus understood, may be concisely termed the cost of production of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages; or, more concisely still, the cost of wages, meaning their cost
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the "original purchase money," labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have now arrived at a distinct conception of Mr. Ricardo's theory of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits in its most perfect state. And this theory we conceive to be the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: basis of the true theory of profits. All that remains to do is to clear
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart
