text: it from certain difficulties which still surround it, and which, though
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in a greater degree apparent than real, are not to be put aside as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wholly imaginary.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Though it is true that tools, materials, and buildings (it is to be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wished that there were some compact designation for all these essentials
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of production taken together,) are themselves the produce of labour, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are only on that account to be ranked among the expenses of production;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: yet the _whole_ of their value is not resolvable into the wages of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourers by whom they were produced. The wages of those labourers were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paid by a capitalist, and that capitalist must have the same profit upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his advances as any other capitalist; when, therefore, he sells the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tools or materials, he must receive from the purchaser not only the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reimbursement of the wages he has paid, but also as much more as will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: afford him the ordinary rate of profit. And when the producer, after
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: buying the tools and employing them in his own occupation, comes to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: estimate his gains, he must set aside a portion of the produce to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: replace not only the wages paid both by himself and by the tool-maker,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but also the profits of the tool-maker, advanced by himself out of his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own capital.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is not correct, therefore, to state that all which the capitalist
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: retains after replacing wages forms his profit. It is true the whole
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: return to capital is either wages or profits; but profits do not compose
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: merely the surplus after replacing the outlay; they also enter into the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: outlay itself. Capital is expended partly in paying or reimbursing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wages, and partly in paying the profits of other capitalists, whose
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: concurrence was necessary in order to bring together the means of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If any contrivance, therefore, were devised by which that part of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: outlay which consists of previous profits could be either wholly or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: partially dispensed with, it is evident that more would remain as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit of the immediate producer; while, as the quantity of _labour_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessary to produce a given quantity of the commodity would be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unaltered, as well as the quantity of produce paid for that labour, it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: seems that the ratio between the price of labour and its produce would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be the same as before; that the cost of production of wages would be the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: same, proportional wages the same, and yet profits different.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To illustrate this by a simple instance, let it be supposed that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one-third of the produce is sufficient to replace the wages of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourers who have been immediately instrumental in the production; that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another third is necessary to replace the materials used and the fixed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital worn out in the process; while the remaining third is clear
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gain, being a profit of 50 per cent. Suppose, for example, that 60
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: agricultural labourers, receiving 60 quarters of corn for their wages,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consume fixed capital and seed amounting to the value of 60 quarters
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more, and that the result of their operations is a produce of 180
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quarters. When we analyse the price of the seed and tools into its
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: elements, we find that they must have been the produce of the labour of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 40 men: for the wages of those 40, together with profit at the rate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: previously supposed (50 per cent) make up 60 quarters. The produce,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, consisting of 180 quarters is the result of the labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: altogether of 100 men: namely, the 60 first mentioned, and the 40 by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whose labour the fixed capital and the seed were produced.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Let us now suppose, by way of an extreme case, that some contrivance is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: discovered, whereby the purposes to which the second third of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce had been devoted, may be dispensed with altogether: that some
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: means are invented by which the same amount of produce may be procured
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: without the assistance of any fixed capital, or the consumption of any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: seed or material sufficiently valuable to be worth calculating. Let us,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: however, suppose that this cannot be done without taking on a number of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: additional labourers, equal to those required for producing the seed and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fixed capital; so that the saving shall be only in the profits of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: previous capitalists. Let us, in conformity with this supposition,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: assume that in dispensing with the fixed capital and seed, value 60
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quarters, it is necessary to take on 40 additional labourers, receiving
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a quarter of corn each, as before.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The rate of profit has evidently risen. It has increased from 50 per
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cent to 60 per cent. A return of 180 quarters could not before be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obtained but by an outlay of 120 quarters; it can now be obtained by an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: outlay of no more than 100.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Here, therefore, is an undeniable rise of profits. Have wages, in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sense above attached to them, fallen or not? It would seem not.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The produce (180 quarters) is still the result of the same quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour as before, namely, the labour of 100 men. A quarter of corn,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, is still, as before, the produce of 10/18 of a man's labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for a year. Each labourer receives, as before, one quarter of corn;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: each, therefore, receives the produce of 10\18 of a year's labour of one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: man, that is, the same cost of production; each receives 10/18 of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce of his own labour, that is, the same proportional wages; and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourers collectively still receive the same proportion, namely 10/18,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the whole produce.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The conclusion, then, cannot be resisted, that Mr. Ricardo's theory is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: defective: that the rate of profits does _not_ exclusively depend upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the value of wages, in his sense, namely, the quantity of labour of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the wages of a labourer are the produce; that it does _not_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exclusively depend upon proportional wages, that is, upon the proportion
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the labourers collectively receive of the whole produce, or the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ratio which the wages of an individual labourer bear to the produce of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his individual labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Those political economists, therefore, who have always dissented from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Mr. Ricardo's doctrine, or who, having at first admitted, ended by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: discarding it, were so far in the right; but they committed a serious
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: error in this, that, with the usual one-sidedness of disputants, they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: knew no medium between admitting absolutely and dismissing entirely;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and saw no other course than utterly to reject what it would have been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sufficient to modify.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is remarkable how very slight a modification will suffice to render
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Mr. Ricardo's doctrine completely true. It is even doubtful whether he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: himself, if called upon to adapt his expressions to this peculiar case,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would not have so explained his doctrine as to render it entirely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unobjectionable.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is perfectly true, that, in the example already made use of, a rise
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of profits takes place, while wages, considered in respect to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quantity of labour of which they are the produce, have not varied at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all. But though wages are still the produce of the same _quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour_ as before, the _cost of production_ of wages has nevertheless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fallen; for into cost of production there enters another element besides
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have already remarked (and the very example out of which the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: difficulty arose presupposes it) that the cost of production of an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: article consists generally of two parts,--the _wages_ of the labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employed, and the _profits_ of those who, in any antecedent stage of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the production, have advanced any portion of those wages. An article,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, may be the produce of the same quantity of labour as before,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and yet, if any portion of the profits which the last producer has to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: make good to previous producers can be economized, the cost of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production of the article is diminished.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now, in our example, a diminution of this sort is supposed to have taken
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place in the cost of production of corn. The production of that article
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: has become less costly, in the ratio of six to five. A quantity of corn,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the means of producing which could not previously have been secured but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at an expense of 120 quarters, can now be produced by means which 100
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quarters are sufficient to purchase.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But the labourer is supposed to receive the same quantity of corn as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: before. He receives one quarter. The cost of production of wages has,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, fallen one-sixth. A quarter of corn, which is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remuneration of a single labourer, is indeed the produce of the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quantity of labour as before; but its cost of production is nevertheless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminished. It is now the produce of 10/18 of a man's labour, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nothing else; whereas formerly it required for its production the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conjunction of that quantity of labour with an expenditure, in the form
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of reimbursement of profit, amounting to one-fifth more.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the cost of production of wages had remained the same as before,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits could not have risen. Each labourer received one quarter of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: corn; but one quarter of corn at that time was the result of the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of production, as 1 1/5 quarter now. In order, therefore, that each
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourer should receive the same cost of production, each must now
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receive one quarter of corn, _plus_ one-fifth. The labour of 100 men
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: could not be purchased at this price for less than 120 quarters; and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce, 180 quarters, would yield only 50 per cent, as first supposed [7].
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is, therefore, strictly true, that the rate of profits varies
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inversely as the cost of production of wages. Profits cannot rise,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unless the cost of production of wages falls exactly as much; nor fall,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unless it rises.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The proof of this position has been stated in figures, and in a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: particular case: we shall now state it in general terms, and for all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cases.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have supposed, for simplicity, that wages are paid in the finished
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodity. The agricultural labourers, in our example, were paid in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: corn, and if we had called them weavers, we should have supposed them to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be paid in cloth. This supposition is allowable, for it is obviously of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no consequence, in a question of value, or cost of production, what
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: precise article we assume as the medium of exchange. The supposition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: has, besides, the recommendation of being conformable to the most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ordinary state of the facts; for it is by the sale of his own finished
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: article that each capitalist obtains the means of hiring labourers to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: renew the production; which is virtually the same thing as if, instead
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of selling the article for money and giving the money to his labourers,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: he gave the article itself to the labourers, and they sold it for their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: daily bread.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Assuming, therefore, that the labourer is paid in the very article he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produces, it is evident that, when any saving of expense takes place in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the production of that article, if the labourer still receives the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cost of production as before, he must receive an increased quantity, in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the very same ratio in which the productive power of capital has been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increased. But, if so, the outlay of the capitalist will bear exactly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same proportion to the return as it did before; and profits will not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rise.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The variations, therefore, in the rate of profits, and those in the cost
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of production of wages, go hand in hand, and are inseparable. Mr.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Ricardo's principle, that profits cannot rise unless wages fall, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: strictly true, if by low wages be meant not merely wages which are the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce of a smaller quantity of labour, but wages which are produced at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: less cost, reckoning labour and previous profits together. But the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interpretation which some economists have put upon Mr. Ricardo's
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: doctrine, when they explain it to mean that profits depend upon the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion which the labourers collectively receive of the aggregate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce, will not hold at all; for that, in our first example, remained
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same, and yet profits rose.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The only expression of the law of profits, which seems to be correct,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is, that they depend upon the cost of production of wages. This must be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: received as the ultimate principle.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: From this may be deduced all the corollaries which Mr. Ricardo and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: others have drawn from his theory of profits as expounded by himself.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The cost of production of the wages of one labourer for a year, is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: result of two concurrent elements or factors,--viz., 1st, the quantity
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of commodities which the state of the labour market affords to him;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2ndly, the cost of production of each of those commodities. It follows,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the rate of profits can never rise but in conjunction with one or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other of two changes,--1st, a diminished remuneration of the labourer;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or, 2ndly, an improvement in production, or an extension of commerce, by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which any of the articles habitually consumed by the labourer may be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obtained at smaller cost. (If the improvement be in any article which is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not consumed by the labourer, it merely lowers the price of that article,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and thereby benefits capitalists and all other people so far as they are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consumers of that particular article, and may be said to increase gross
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profit, but not the rate of profit.)
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: So, on the other hand, the rate of profit cannot fall, unless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: concurrently with one of two events: 1st, an improvement in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labourer's condition; or, 2ndly, an increased difficulty of producing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or importing some article which the labourer habitually consumes. The
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: progress of population and cultivation has a tendency to lower profits
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: through the latter of these two channels, owing to the well known law
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the application of capital to land, that a double capital does not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _caeteris paribus_ yield a double produce. There is, therefore, a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tendency in the rate of profits to fall with the progress of society.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But there is also an antagonist tendency of profits to rise, by the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: successive introduction of improvements in agriculture, and in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: production of those manufactured articles which the labourers consume.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Supposing, therefore, that the actual comforts of the labourer remain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same, profits will fall or rise, according as population, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: improvements in the production of food and other necessaries, advance
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fastest.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The rate of profits, therefore, tends to _fall_ from the following
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: causes:--1. An increase of capital beyond population, producing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increased competition for labour; 2. An increase of population,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: occasioning a demand for an increased quantity of food, which must be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produced at a greater cost. The rate of profits tends to _rise_ from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the following causes:--1. An increase of population beyond capital,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producing increased competition for employment; 2. Improvements
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producing increased cheapness of necessaries, and other articles
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: habitually consumed by the labourer.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The circumstances which regulate the rate of interest have usually been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: treated, even by professed writers on political economy, in a vague,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: loose, and unscientific manner. It has, however, been felt that there is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some connexion between the rate of interest and the rate of profit; that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (to use the words of Adam Smith) much will be given for money, when much
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: can be made of it. It has been felt, also, that the fluctuations in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: market-rate of interest from day to day, are determined, like other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matters of bargain and sale, by demand and supply. It has, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been considered as an established principle, that the rate of interest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: varies from day to day according to the quantity of capital offered or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: called for on loan; but conforms on the average of years to a standard
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: determined by the rate of profits, and bearing some proportion to that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rate--but a proportion which few attempts have been made to define.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In consequence of these views, it has been customary to judge of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: general rate of profits at any time or place, by the rate of interest at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that time and place: it being supposed that the rate of interest, though
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: liable to temporary fluctuations, can never vary for any long period of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: time unless profits vary; a notion which appears to us to be erroneous.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It was observed by Adam Smith, that profits may be considered as divided
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: into two parts, of which one may properly be considered as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: remuneration for the use of the capital itself, the other as the reward
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the labour of superintending its employment; and that the former of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: these will correspond with the rate of interest. The producer who
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: borrows capital to employ it in his business, will consent to pay, for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the use of it, all that remains of the profits he can make by it, after
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reserving what he considers reasonable remuneration for the trouble and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: risk which he incurs by borrowing and employing it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This remark is just; but it seems necessary to give greater precision to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the ideas which it involves.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The difference between the profit which can be made by the use of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, and the interest which will be paid for it, is rightly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: characterized as wages of superintendance. But to infer from this that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it is regulated by entirely the same principles as other wages, would be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to push the analogy too far. It is wages, but wages paid by a commission
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon the capital employed. If the general rate of profit is 10 per cent,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and the rate of interest 5 per cent, the wages of superintendance will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be 5 per cent; and though one borrower employ a capital of 100,000_l_.,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another no more than 100_l_., the labour of both will be rewarded with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same per centage, though, in the one ease, this symbol will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: represent an income of 5_l_., in the other case, of 5000_l_. Yet it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cannot be pretended that the labour of the two borrowers differs in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion. The rule, therefore, that equal quantities of labour of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equal hardness and skill are equally remunerated, does not hold of this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: kind of labour. The wages of any other labour are here an inapplicable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: criterion.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The wages of superintendance are distinguished from ordinary wages by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another peculiarity, that they are not paid in advance out of capital,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: like the wages of all other labourers, but merge in the profit, and are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not realized until the production is completed. This takes them entirely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: out of the ordinary law of wages. The wages of labourers who are paid in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: advance, are regulated by the number of competitors compared with the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: amount of capital; the labourers can consume no more than what has been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: previously accumulated. But there is no such limit to the remuneration
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a kind of labour which is not paid for out of wealth previously
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accumulated, but out of that produce which it is itself employed in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: calling into existence.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When these circumstances are duly weighed, it will be perceived, that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: although profit may be correctly analyzed into interest and wages of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superintendance, we ought not to lay it down as the law of interest,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that it is profits _minus_ the wages of superintendance. Of the two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: expressions, it would be decidedly the more correct, that the wages of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superintendance are regulated by the rate of interest, or are equal to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profits _minus_ interest. In strict, propriety, neither expression would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be allowable. Interest, and the wages of superintendance, can scarcely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be said to depend upon one another. They are to one another in the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: relation as wages and profits are. They are like two buckets in a well:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: when one rises, the other descends, but neither of the two motions is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the cause of the other; both are simultaneous effects of the same cause,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the turning of the windlass.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There are among the capitalists of every country a considerable number
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who are habitually, and almost necessarily, lenders; to whom scarcely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any difference between what they could receive for their money and what
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: could be made by it, would be an equivalent for incurring the risk and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: labour of carrying on business. In this predicament is the property of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: widows and orphans; of many public bodies; of charitable institutions;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: most property which is vested in trustees; and the property of a great
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: number of persons unused to business, and who have a distaste for it,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or whose other occupations prevent their engaging in it. How large a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportion of the property lent to the nation comes under this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: description, has been pointed out in Mr. Tooke's _Considerations on the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: State of the Currency._
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There is another large class, consisting of bankers, bill-brokers, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: others, who are money-lenders by profession; who enter into that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: profession with the intention of making such gains as it will yield
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them, and who would not be induced to change their business by any but
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a very strong pecuniary inducement.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There is, therefore, a large class of persons who are habitually
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: lenders. On the other hand, all persons in business may be considered
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as habitually borrowers. Except in times of stagnation, they are all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desirous of extending their business beyond their own capital, and are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: never desirous of lending any portion of their capital except for very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: short periods, during which they cannot advantageously invest it in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their own trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There is, in short, a productive class, and there is, besides, a class
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: technically styled the monied class, who live upon the interest of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, without engaging personally in the work of production.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The class of borrowers may be considered as unlimited. There is no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: quantity of capital that could be offered to be lent, which the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: productive classes would not be willing to borrow, at any rate of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest which would afford them the slightest excess of profit above a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: bare equivalent for the additional risk, incurred by that transaction,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the evils attendant on insolvency. The only assignable limit to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inclination to borrow, is the power of giving security: the producers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would find it difficult to borrow more than an amount equal to their own
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital. If more than half the capital of the country were in the hands
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of persons who preferred lending it to engaging personally in business,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and if the surplus were greater than could be invested in loans to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Government, or in mortgages upon the property of unproductive consumers;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the competition of lenders would force down the rate of interest very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: low. A certain portion of the monied class would be obliged either to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sacrifice their predilections by engaging in business, or to lend on
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inferior security; and they would accordingly accept, where they could
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obtain good security, an abatement of interest equivalent to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: difference of risk.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This is an extreme case. Let us put an extreme case of a contrary kind.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Suppose that the wealthy people of any country, not relishing an idle
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: life, and having a strong taste for gainful labour, were generally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indisposed to accept of a smaller income in order to be relieved from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the labour and anxiety of business. Every producer in flourishing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: circumstances would be eager to borrow, and few willing to lend. Under
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: these circumstances the rate of interest would differ very little from
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the rate of profit. The trouble of managing a business is not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: proportionally increased by an increase of the magnitude of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: business; and a very small surplus profit above the rate of interest,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would therefore be a sufficient inducement to capitalists to borrow.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We may even conceive a people whose habits were such, that in order to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: induce them to lend, it might be necessary to offer them a rate of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest fully equal to the ordinary rate of profit. In that case, of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: course, the productive classes would scarcely ever borrow. But
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: government, and the unproductive classes, who do not borrow in order to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: make a profit by the loan, but from the pressure of a real or supposed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessity, might still be ready to borrow at this high rate.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Although the inclination to borrow has no _fixed_ or _necessary_ limit
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: except the power of giving security, yet it always, in point of fact,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: stops short of this; from the uncertainty of the prospects of any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: individual producer, which generally indisposes him to involve himself
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the full extent of his means of payment. There is never any permanent
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: want of market for things in general; but there may be so for the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: commodity which any one individual is producing; and even if there is a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: demand for the commodity, people may not buy it of him but of some other.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: There are, consequently, never more than a portion of the producers, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: state of whose business encourages them to add to their capital by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: borrowing; and even these are disposed to borrow only as much as they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: see an _immediate_ prospect of profitably employing. There is, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a practical limit to the demands of borrowers at any given instant; and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: when these demands are all satisfied, any additional capital offered on
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: loan can find an investment only by a reduction of the rate of interest.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The amount of borrowers being given, (and by the amount of borrowers is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: here meant the aggregate sum which people are willing to borrow at some
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: given rate,) the rate of interest will depend upon the quantity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital owned by people who are unwilling or unable to engage in trade.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The circumstances which determine this, are, on the one hand, the degree
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in which a taste for business, or an aversion to it, happens to be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: prevalent among the classes possessed of property; and on the other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hand, the amount of the annual accumulation from the earnings of labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Those who accumulate from their wages, fees, or salaries, have, of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: course, (speaking generally) no means of investing their savings except
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by lending them to others: their occupations prevent them from personally
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: superintending any employment.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Upon these circumstances, then, the rate of interest depends, the amount
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of borrowers being given. And the counter-proposition equally holds,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that, the above circumstances being given, the rate of interest depends
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon the amount of borrowers.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Suppose, for example, that when the rate of interest has adjusted itself
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the existing state of the circumstances which affect the disposition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to borrow and to lend, a war breaks out, which induces government, for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a series of years, to borrow annually a large sum of money. During the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whole of this period, the rate of interest will remain considerably
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: above what it was before, and what it will be afterwards.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Before the commencement of the supposed war, all persons who were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disposed to lend at the then rate of interest, had found borrowers, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their capital was invested. This may be assumed; for if any capital had
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been seeking for a borrower at the existing rate of interest, and unable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to find one, its owner would have offered it at a rate slightly below
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the existing rate. He would, for instance, have bought into the funds,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at a slight advance of price; and thus set at liberty the capital of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some fundholder, who, the funds yielding a lower interest, would have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been obliged to accept a lower interest from individuals.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Since, then, all who were willing to lend their capital at the market
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rate, have already lent it, Government will not be able to borrow unless
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by offering higher interest. Though, with the existing habits of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possessors of disposable capital, an increased number cannot be found
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who are willing to lend at the existing rate, there are doubtless some
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who will be induced to lend by the temptation of a higher rate. The same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: temptation will also induce some persons to invest, in the purchase of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the new stock, what they would otherwise have expended unproductively in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increasing their establishments, or productively, in improving their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: estates. The rate of interest will rise just sufficiently to call forth
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: an increase of lenders to the amount required.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This we apprehend to be the cause why the rate of interest in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: country was so high as it is well known to have been during the last
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: war. It is, therefore, by no means to be inferred, as some have done,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that the general rate of profits was unusually high during the same
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: period, because interest was so. Supposing the rate of profits to have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: been precisely the same during the war, as before or after it, the rate
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of interest would nevertheless have risen, from the causes and in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: manner above described.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The practical use of the preceding investigation is, to moderate the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: confidence with which inferences are frequently drawn with respect to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the rate of profit from evidence regarding the rate of interest; and to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: shew that although the rate of profit is one of the elements which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: combine to determine the rate of interest, the latter is also acted upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by causes peculiar to itself, and may either rise or fall, both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: temporarily and permanently, while the general rate of profits remains
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unchanged.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The introduction of banks, which perform the function of lenders and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: loan-brokers, with or without that of issuers of paper-money, produces
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some further anomalies in the rate of interest, which have not, so far
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as we are aware, been hitherto brought within the pale of exact science.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If bankers were merely a class of middlemen between the lender and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: borrower; if they merely received deposits of capital from those who had
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it lying unemployed in their hands, and lent this, together with their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own capital, to the productive classes, receiving interest for it, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paying interest in their turn to those who had placed capital in their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hands; the effect of the operations of banking on the rate of interest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would be to lower it in some slight degree. The banker receives and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: collects together sums of money much too small, when taken individually,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to render it worth while for the owners to look out for an investment,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but which in the aggregate form a considerable amount. This amount may
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be considered a clear addition to the productive capital of the country;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: at least, to the capital in activity at any moment. And as this addition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the capital accrues wholly to that part of it which is not employed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: by the owners, but lent to other producers, the natural effect is a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: diminution of the rate of interest.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The banker, to the extent of his own private capital, (the expenses of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his business being first paid,) is a lender at interest. But, being
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subject to risk and trouble fully equal to that which belongs to most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other employments, he cannot be satisfied with the mere interest even
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of his whole capital: he must have the ordinary profits of stock, or he
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will not engage in the business: the state of banking must be such as to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hold out to him the prospect of adding, to the interest of what remains
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of his own capital after paying the expenses of his business, interest
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon capital deposited with him, in sufficient amount to make up, after
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paying the expenses, the ordinary profit which could be derived from his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own capital in any productive employment. This will be accomplished in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one of two ways.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 1. If the circumstances of society are such as to furnish a ready
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: investment of disposable capital; (as for instance in London, where the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: public funds and other securities, of undoubted stability, and affording
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: great advantages for receiving the interest without trouble and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: realizing the principal without difficulty when required, tempt all
