title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: persons who have sums of importance lying idle, to invest them on their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: own account without the intervention of any middleman;) the deposits
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with bankers consist chiefly of small sums likely to be wanted in a very
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: short period for current expenses, and the interest on which would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: seldom be worth the trouble of calculating it. Bankers, therefore, do
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not allow any interest on their deposits. After paying the expenses of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their business, all the rest of the interest they receive is clear gain.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But as the circumstances of banking, as of all other modes of employing
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital, will on the average be such as to afford to a person entering
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: into the business a prospect of realizing the ordinary, and no more than
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the ordinary, profits upon his own capital; the gains of each banker by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the investment of his deposits, will not on the average exceed what is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessary to make up his gains on his own capital to the ordinary rate.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is, of course, competition, which brings about this limitation.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Whether competition operates by lowering the rate of interest, or by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: dividing the business among a larger number, it is difficult to decide.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Probably it operates in both ways; but it is by no means impossible that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it may operate in the latter way alone: just as an increase in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: number of physicians does not lower the fees, though it diminishes an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: average competitor's chance of obtaining them.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It is not impossible that the disposition of the lenders might be such,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that they would cease to lend rather than acquiesce in any reduction of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the rate of interest. If so, the arrival of a new lender, in the person
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a banker of deposit, would not lower the rate of interest in any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: considerable degree. A slight fall would take place, and with that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exception things would be as before, except that the capital in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hands of the banker would have put itself into the place of an equal
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: portion of capital belonging to other lenders, who would themselves have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: engaged in business (e.g., by subscribing to some joint-stock company,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or entering into commandite). Bankers' profits would then be limited to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the ordinary rate chiefly by the division of the business among many
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: banks, so that each on the average would receive no more interest on his
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: deposits than would suffice to make up the interest on his own capital
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the ordinary rate of profit after paying all expenses.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 2. But if the circumstances of society render it difficult and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inconvenient for persons who wish to live upon the interest of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money, to seek an investment for themselves, the bankers become agents
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for this specific purpose: large as well as small sums are deposited
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with them, and they allow interest to their customers. Such is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: practice of the Scotch banks, and of most of the country banks in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: England. Their customers, not living at any of the great seats of money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: transactions, prefer entrusting their capital to somebody on the spot,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whom they know, and in whom they confide. He invests their money on the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: best terms he can, and pays to them such interest as he can afford to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: give; retaining a compensation for his own risk and trouble. This
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: compensation is fixed by the competition of the market. The rate of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest is no further lowered by this operation, than inasmuch as it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: brings together the lender and the borrower in a safe and expeditious
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: manner. The lender incurs less risk, and a larger proportion, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the holders of capital are willing to be lenders.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When a banker, in addition to his other functions, is also an issuer of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: paper money, he gains an advantage similar to that which the London
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: bankers derive from their deposits. To the extent to which he can put
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: forth his notes, he has so much the more to lend, without himself having
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to pay any interest for it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the paper is convertible, it cannot get into circulation permanently
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: without displacing specie, which goes abroad and brings back an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: equivalent value. To the extent of this value, there is an increase of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the capital of the country; and the increase accrues solely to that part
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the capital which is employed in loans.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If the paper is inconvertible, and instead of displacing specie
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: depreciates the currency, the banker by issuing it levies a tax on every
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: person who has money in his hands or due to him. He thus appropriates to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: himself a portion of the capital of other people, and a portion of their
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: revenue. The capital might have been intended to be lent, or it might
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have been intended to be employed by the owner: such part of it as was
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: intended to be employed by the owner now changes its destination, and is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: lent. The revenue was either intended to be accumulated, in which case
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it had already become capital, or it was intended to be spent: in this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: last case, revenue is converted into capital: and thus, strange as it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: may appear, the depreciation of the currency, when effected in this way,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: operates to a certain extent as a forced accumulation. This, indeed, is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no palliation of its iniquity. Though A might have spent his property
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: unproductively, B ought not to be permitted to rob him of it because B
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will expend it on productive labour.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In any supposable case, however, the issue of paper money by bankers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: increases the proportion of the whole capital of the country which is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: destined to be lent. The rate of interest must therefore fall, until
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some of the lenders give over lending, or until the increase of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: borrowers absorbs the whole.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But a fall of the rate of interest, sufficient to enable the money
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: market to absorb the whole of the paper-loans, may not be sufficient to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reduce the profits of a lender who lends what costs him nothing, to the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ordinary rate of profit upon his capital. Here, therefore, competition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will operate chiefly by dividing the business. The notes of each bank
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: will be confined within so narrow a district, or will divide the supply
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of a district with so many other banks, that on the average each will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: receive no larger amount of interest on his notes than will make up the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: interest on his own capital to the ordinary rate of profit.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Even in this way, however, the competition has the effect, to a certain
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: limited extent, of lowering the rate of interest; for the power of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: bankers to receive interest on more than their capital attracts a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: greater amount of capital into the banking business than would otherwise
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: flow into it; and this greater capital being all lent, interest will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fall in consequence.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: NOTE:
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: [7] It would be easy to go over in the same manner any other case. For
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instance, we may suppose, that, instead of dispensing with the _whole_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the fixed capital, material, &c, and taking on labourers in equal
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: number to those by whom these were produced, _half_ only of the fixed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: capital and material is dispensed with; so that, instead of 60 labourers
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and a fixed capital worth 6O quarters of corn, we have 80 labourers and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a fixed capital worth 30. The numerical statement of this case is more
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: intricate than that in the text, but the result is not different.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ESSAY V.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ON THE DEFINITION OF POLITICAL ECONOMY; AND ON THE METHOD OF
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: INVESTIGATION PROPER TO IT.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It might be imagined, on a superficial view of the nature and objects of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: definition, that the definition of a science would occupy the same place
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the chronological which it commonly does in the didactic order. As a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: treatise on any science usually commences with an attempt to express, in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a brief formula, what the science is, and wherein it differs from other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: sciences, so, it might be supposed, did the framing of such a formula
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: naturally precede the successful cultivation of the science.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This, however, is far from having been the case. The definition of a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: science has almost invariably not preceded, but followed, the creation
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the science itself. Like the wall of a city, it has usually been
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: erected, not to be a receptacle for such edifices as might afterwards
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: spring up, but to circumscribe an aggregation already in existence.

text: with the distinction between the truths which concern all kinds of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: these are admitted to be correctly placed in the science of Political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Economy.

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The real distinction between Political Economy and physical science must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be sought in something deeper than the nature of the subject-matter;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which, indeed, is for the most part common to both. Political Economy,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and the scientific grounds of all the useful arts, have in truth one and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the same subject-matter; namely, the objects which conduce to man's
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: convenience and enjoyment: but they are, nevertheless, perfectly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distinct branches of knowledge.

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: 3. If we contemplate the whole field of human knowledge, attained or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: attainable, we find that it separates itself obviously, and as it were
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: spontaneously, into two divisions, which stand so strikingly in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: opposition and contradistinction to one another, that in all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: classifications of our knowledge they have been kept apart. These are,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _physical_ science, and _moral_ or psychological science. The difference
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: between these two departments of our knowledge does not reside in the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subject-matter with which they are conversant: for although, of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: simplest and most elementary parts of each, it may be said, with an
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: approach to truth, that they are concerned with different subject-
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matters--namely, the one with the human mind, the other with all things
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: whatever except the mind; this distinction does not hold between the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: higher regions of the two. Take the science of politics, for instance,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or that of law: who will say that these are physical sciences? and yet
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is it not obvious that they are conversant fully as much with matter as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with mind? Take, again, the theory of music, of painting, of any other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the fine arts, and who will venture to pronounce that the facts they
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are conversant with belong either wholly to the class of matter, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wholly to that of mind?
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The following seems to be the _rationale_ of the distinction between
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: physical and moral science.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In all the intercourse of man with nature, whether we consider him as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: acting upon it, or as receiving impressions from it, the effect or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: phenomenon depends upon causes of two kinds: the properties of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: object acting, and those of the object acted upon. Everything which can
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possibly happen in which man and external things, are jointly concerned,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: results from the joint operation of a law or laws of matter, and a law
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: or laws of the human mind. Thus the production of corn by human labour
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is the result of a law of mind, and many laws of matter. The laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matter are those properties of the soil and of vegetable life which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cause the seed to germinate in the ground, and those properties of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: human body which render food necessary to its support. The law of mind
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is, that man desires to possess subsistence, and consequently wills the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: necessary means of procuring it.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Laws of mind and laws of matter are so dissimilar in their nature, that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it would be contrary to all principles of rational arrangement to mix
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them up as part of the same study. In all scientific methods, therefore,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they are placed apart. Any compound effect or phenomenon which depends
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: both on the properties of matter and on those of mind, may thus become
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the subject of two completely distinct sciences, or branches of science;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one, treating of the phenomenon in so far as it depends upon the laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matter only; the other treating of it in so far as it depends upon the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: laws of mind.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The physical sciences are those which treat of the laws of matter, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of all complex phenomena in so far as dependent upon the laws of matter.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The mental or moral sciences are those which treat of the laws of mind,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and of all complex phenomena in so far as dependent upon the laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mind.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Most of the moral sciences presuppose physical science; but few of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: physical sciences presuppose moral science. The reason is obvious. There
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are many phenomena (an earthquake, for example, or the motions of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: planets) which depend upon the laws of matter exclusively; and have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nothing whatever to do with the laws of mind. Many, therefore, of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: physical sciences may be treated of without any reference to mind, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as if the mind existed as a recipient of knowledge only, not as a cause
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: producing effects. But there are no phenomena which depend exclusively
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon the laws of mind; even the phenomena of the mind itself being
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: partially dependent upon the physiological laws of the body. All the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mental sciences, therefore, not excepting the pure science of mind, must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: take account of a great variety of physical truths; and (as physical
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: science is commonly and very properly studied first) may be said to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: presuppose them, taking up the complex phenomena where physical science
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: leaves them.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now this, it will be found, is a precise statement of the relation in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which Political Economy stands to the various sciences which are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: tributary to the arts of production.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The laws of the production of the objects which constitute wealth, are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the subject-matter both of Political Economy and of almost all the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: physical sciences. Such, however, of those laws as are purely laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: matter, belong to physical science, and to that exclusively. Such of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them as are laws of the human mind, and no others, belong to Political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Economy, which finally sums up the result of both combined.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Political Economy, therefore, presupposes all the physical sciences; it
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: takes for granted all such of the truths of those sciences as are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: concerned in the production of the objects demanded by the wants of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mankind; or at least it takes for granted that the physical part of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: process takes place somehow. It then inquires what are the phenomena of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: _mind_ which are concerned in the production and distribution [8] of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those same objects; it borrows from the pure science of mind the laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those phenomena, and inquires what effects follow from these mental
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: laws, acting in concurrence with those physical one. [9]
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: From the above considerations the following seems to come out as the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: correct and complete definition of Political Economy:--"The science
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which treats of the production and distribution of wealth, so far as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: they depend upon the laws of human nature." Or thus--science relating to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the moral or psychological laws of the production and distribution of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wealth."
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: For popular use this definition is amply sufficient, but it still falls
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: short of the complete accuracy required for the purposes of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: philosopher. Political Economy does not treat of the production and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distribution of wealth in all states of mankind, but only in what is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: termed the social state; nor so far as they depend upon the laws of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: human nature, but only so far as they depend upon a certain portion of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those laws. This, at least, is the view which must be taken of Political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Economy, if we mean it to find any place in an encyclopedical division
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the field of science. On any other view, it either is not science at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all, or it is several sciences. This will appear clearly, if, on the one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hand, we take a general survey of the moral sciences, with a view to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: assign the exact place of Political Economy among them; while, on the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other, we consider attentively the nature of the methods or processes by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the truths which are the object of those sciences are arrived at.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Man, who, considered as a being having a moral or mental nature, is the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: subject-matter of all the moral sciences, may, with reference to that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: part of his nature, form the subject of philosophical inquiry under
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: several distinct hypotheses. We may inquire what belongs to man
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: considered individually, and as if no human being existed besides
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: himself; we may next consider him as coming into contact with other
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: individuals; and finally, as living in a state of _society_, that is,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: forming part of a body or aggregation of human beings, systematically
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: co-operating for common purposes. Of this last state, political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: government, or subjection to a common superior, is an ordinary
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ingredient, but forms no necessary part of the conception, and, with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: respect to our present purpose, needs not be further adverted to.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Those laws or properties of human nature which appertain to man as a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mere individual, and do not presuppose, as a necessary condition, the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: existence of other individuals (except, perhaps, as mere instruments or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: means), form a part of the subject of pure mental philosophy. They
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: comprise all the laws of the mere intellect, and those of the purely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: self-regarding desires.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Those laws of human nature which relate to the feelings called forth in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a human being by other individual human or intelligent beings, as such;
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: namely, the _affections_, the _conscience_, or feeling of duty, and the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: love of _approbation_; and to the conduct of man, so far as it depends
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: upon, or has relation to, these parts of his nature--form the subject of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: another portion of pure mental philosophy, namely, that portion of it on
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which _morals_, or _ethics_, are founded. For morality itself is not a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: science, but an art; not truths, but rules. The truths on which the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rules are founded are drawn (as is the case in all arts) from a variety
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of sciences; but the principal of them, and those which are most nearly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: peculiar to this particular art, belong to a branch of the science of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mind.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Finally, there are certain principles of human nature which are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: peculiarly connected with the ideas and feelings generated in man by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: aggregation of human beings for a common purpose or purposes. Few,

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: state, almost all being called into action in the two other states. But
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those simple laws of human nature, operating in that wider field, give
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: rise to results of a sufficiently universal character, and even (when

text: compared with the still more complex phenomena of which they are the

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: determining causes) sufficiently simple, to admit of being called,

text: though in a somewhat looser sense, _laws_ of society, or laws of human

text: nature in the social state. These laws, or general truths, form the

text: subject of a branch of science which may be aptly designated from the

text: politics_, or the _science_ of politics, as contradistinguished from the

text: art. This science stands in the same relation to the social, as anatomy

text: another; and what are the effects of each upon the conduct and character

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of man.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This branch of science, whether we prefer to call it social economy,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: speculative politics, or the natural history of society, presupposes the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: What is now commonly understood by the term "Political Economy" is not
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the science of speculative politics, but a branch of that science. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: does not treat of the whole of man's nature as modified by the social
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: state, nor of the whole conduct of man in society. It is concerned with
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: him solely as a being who desires to possess wealth, and who is capable
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of judging of the comparative efficacy of means for obtaining that end.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It predicts only such of the phenomena of the social state as take place
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in consequence of the pursuit of wealth. It makes entire abstraction of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: every other human passion or motive; except those which may be regarded
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as perpetually antagonizing principles to the desire of wealth, namely,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: aversion to labour, and desire of the present enjoyment of costly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indulgences. These it takes, to a certain extent, into its calculations,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: because these do not merely, like other desires, occasionally conflict
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with the pursuit of wealth, but accompany it always as a drag, or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: impediment, and are therefore inseparably mixed up in the consideration
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of it. Political Economy considers mankind as occupied solely in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: acquiring and consuming wealth; and aims at showing what is the course
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of action into which mankind, living in a state of society, would be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: impelled, if that motive, except in the degree in which it is checked by
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the two perpetual counter-motives above adverted to, were absolute ruler
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of all their actions. Under the influence of this desire, it shows
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mankind accumulating wealth, and employing that wealth in the production
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of other wealth; sanctioning by mutual agreement the institution of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: property; establishing laws to prevent individuals from encroaching upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the property of others by force or fraud; adopting various contrivances
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for increasing the productiveness of their labour; settling the division
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the produce by agreement, under the influence of competition
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: (competition itself being governed by certain laws, which laws are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore the ultimate regulators of the division of the produce); and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: employing certain expedients (as money, credit, &c.) to facilitate the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distribution. All these operations, though many of them are really the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: result of a plurality of motives, are considered by Political Economy as
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: flowing solely from the desire of wealth. The science then proceeds to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: investigate the laws which govern these several operations, under the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: supposition that man is a being who is determined, by the necessity of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: his nature, to prefer a greater portion of wealth to a smaller in all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cases, without any other exception than that constituted by the two
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: counter-motives already specified. Not that any political economist was
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ever so absurd as to suppose that mankind are really thus constituted,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but because this is the mode in which science must necessarily proceed.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: When an effect depends upon a concurrence of causes, those causes must
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be studied one at a time, and their laws separately investigated, if we
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: wish, through the causes, to obtain the power of either predicting or
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: controlling the effect; since the law of the effect is compounded of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: laws of all the causes which determine it. The law of the centripetal
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and that of the tangential force must have been known before the motions
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of the earth and planets could be explained, or many of them predicted.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The same is the case with the conduct of man in society. In order to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: judge how he will act under the variety of desires and aversions which
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are concurrently operating upon him, we must know how he would act under
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the exclusive influence of each one in particular. There is, perhaps, no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: action of a man's life in which he is neither under the immediate nor
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: under the remote influence of any impulse but the mere desire of wealth.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: With respect to those parts of human conduct of which wealth is not even
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the principal object, to these Political Economy does not pretend that
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its conclusions are applicable. But there are also certain departments
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of human affairs, in which the acquisition of wealth is the main and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: acknowledged end. It is only of these that Political Economy takes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: notice. The manner in which it necessarily proceeds is that of treating
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the main and acknowledged end as if it were the sole end; which, of all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hypotheses equally simple, is the nearest to the truth. The political
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: economist inquires, what are the actions which would be produced by this
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desire, if, within the departments in question, it were unimpeded by any
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: other. In this way a nearer approximation is obtained than would
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: otherwise be practicable, to the real order of human affairs in those
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: departments. This approximation is then to be corrected by making proper
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: allowance for the effects of any impulses of a different description,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which can be shown to interfere with the result in any particular case.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Only in a few of the most striking cases (such as the important one of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the principle of population) are these corrections interpolated into the

text: expositions of Political Economy itself; the strictness of purely
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: sake of practical utility. So far as it is known, or may be presumed,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: the desire of obtaining the greatest quantity of wealth with the least

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: any other object."

text: matter-of-fact or detail,--the cause will be found to be, a difference

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: subject. They differ not solely in what they believe themselves to see,

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The most universal of the forms in which this difference of method is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accustomed to present itself, is the ancient feud between what is called
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: theory, and what is called practice or experience. There are, on social
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and political questions, two kinds of reasoners: there is one portion
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: who term themselves practical men, and call the others theorists; a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: title which the latter do not reject, though they by no means recognise
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it as peculiar to them. The distinction between the two is a very broad
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one, though it is one of which the language employed is a most incorrect
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: exponent. It has been again and again demonstrated, that those who are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: accused of despising facts and disregarding experience build and profess
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to build wholly upon facts and experience; while those who disavow
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: theory cannot make one step without theorizing. But, although both
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: classes of inquirers do nothing but theorize, and both of them consult
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: no other guide than experience, there is this difference between them,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and a most important difference it is: that those who are called
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: practical men require _specific_ experience, and argue wholly _upwards_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from particular facts to a general conclusion; while those who are
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: called theorists aim at embracing a wider field of experience, and,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: having argued upwards from particular facts to a general principle

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: including a much wider range than that of the question under discussion,

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: then argue _downwards_ from that general principle to a variety of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: specific conclusions.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Suppose, for example, that the question were, whether absolute kings
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: were likely to employ the powers of government for the welfare or for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the oppression of their subjects. The practicals would endeavour to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: determine this question by a direct induction from the conduct of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: particular despotic monarchs, as testified by history. The theorists
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: would refer the question to be decided by the test not solely of our
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: experience of kings, but of our experience of men. They would contend
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that an observation of the tendencies which human nature has manifested
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the variety of situations in which human beings have been placed, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: especially observation of what passes in our own minds, warrants us in
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inferring that a human being in the situation of a despotic king will
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: make a bad use of power; and that this conclusion would lose nothing of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its certainty even if absolute kings had never existed, or if history
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: furnished us with no information of the manner in which they had
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conducted themselves.

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The first of these methods is a method of induction, merely; the last a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mixed method of induction and ratiocination. The first may be called the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: method _a posteriori;_ the latter, the method _a priori_. We are aware
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that this last expression is sometimes used to characterize a supposed
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: mode of philosophizing, which does not profess to be founded upon
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: experience at all. But we are not acquainted with any mode of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: philosophizing, on political subjects at least, to which such a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: description is fairly applicable. By the method _a posteriori_ we mean
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that which requires, as the basis of its conclusions, not experience
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: merely, but specific experience. By the method _a priori_ we mean (what
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: has commonly been meant) reasoning from an assumed hypothesis; which is
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not a practice confined to mathematics, but is of the essence of all
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: science which admits of general reasoning at all. To verify the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: hypothesis itself _a posteriori_, that is, to examine whether the facts
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of any actual case are in accordance with it, is no part of the business
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of science at all, but of the _application_ of science.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: In the definition which we have attempted to frame of the science of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Political Economy, we have characterized it as essentially an _abstract_
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: science, and its method as the method _a priori_. Such is undoubtedly
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: its character as it has been understood and taught by all its most
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: distinguished teachers. It reasons, and, as we contend, must necessarily
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reason, from assumptions, not from facts. It is built upon hypotheses,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: strictly analogous to those which, under the name of definitions, are

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Economy, as the definition of a line is prefixed to Euclid's Elements;

text: and in proportion as by being so prefixed it would be less in danger of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: being forgotten, we may see ground for regret that this is not done. It
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: is proper that what is assumed in every particular case, should once for
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all be brought before the mind in its full extent, by being somewhere
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: formally stated as a general maxim. Now, no one who is conversant with

text: We cannot, therefore, too carefully endeavour to verify our theory, by

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: circumstances.

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: No one who attempts to lay down propositions for the guidance of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy

text: predict with absolute certainty, but only with a less or greater degree
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of probability; according as they are better or worse apprised what the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: causes are,--have learnt with more or less accuracy from experience the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: law to which each of those causes, when acting separately, conforms,--and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: have summed up the aggregate effect more or less carefully.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: With all the precautions which have been indicated there will still be
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some danger of falling into partial views; but we shall at least have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: taken the best securities against it. All that we can do more, is to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: endeavour to be impartial critics of our own theories, and to free
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: ourselves, as far as we are able, from that reluctance from which few
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: inquirers are altogether exempt, to admit the reality or relevancy of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any facts which they have not previously either taken into, or left a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place open for in, their systems.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If indeed every phenomenon was generally the effect of no more than one
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cause, a knowledge of the law of that cause would, unless there was a
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: logical error in our reasoning, enable us confidently to predict all the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: circumstances of the phenomenon. We might then, if we had carefully
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: examined our premises and our reasoning, and found no flaw, venture to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disbelieve the testimony which might be brought to show that matters had
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: turned out differently from what we should have predicted. If the causes
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of erroneous conclusions were always patent on the face of the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reasonings which lead to them, the human understanding would be a far
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more trustworthy instrument than it is. But the narrowest examination of
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the process itself will help us little towards discovering that we have
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: omitted part of the premises which we ought to have taken into our
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: reasoning. Effects are commonly determined by a _concurrence_ of causes.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: If we have overlooked any one cause, we may reason justly from all the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: others, and only be the further wrong. Our premises will be true, and
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: our reasoning correct, and yet the result of no value in the particular
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: case. There is, therefore, almost always room for a modest doubt as to
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: our practical conclusions. Against false premises and unsound reasoning,
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a good mental discipline may effectually secure us; but against the
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: danger of _overlooking_ something, neither strength of understanding nor
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: intellectual cultivation can be more than a very imperfect protection.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: A person may be warranted in feeling confident, that whatever he has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carefully contemplated with his mind's eye he has seen correctly; but no
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one can be sure that there is not something in existence which he has
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not seen at all. He can do no more than satisfy himself that he has seen
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: all that is visible to any other persons who have concerned themselves
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: with the subject. For this purpose he must endeavour to place himself at
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: their point of view, and strive earnestly to see the object as they see
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it; nor give up the attempt until he has either added the appearance
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which is floating before them to his own stock of realities, or made out
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: clearly that it is an optical deception.
title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Essays on some unsettled Questions of Political Economy
